{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name=Alumni Stadium | location=26 Powerhouse Lane
[[Guelph]], [[Ontario]], Canada N1G 2W1 | image=Homecoming-crowd-in-Alumni-Stadium Photographer-Richard-Bain.jpg | image_size=250px | opened=1970 | renovated=2012 | surface= [[FieldTurf Revolution]] (2012-present)
Grass (1970-2012) | owner= [[University of Guelph]] | construction_cost= Unknown | tenants= [[Guelph Gryphons]] ([[U Sports]]) (1970-present)
[[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] ([[Canadian Football League|CFL]]) (2013) | architect= Unknown | seating_capacity= [[U Sports]] football: 8,500
[[Canadian Football League|CFL]] football: 13,362 }} '''Alumni Stadium''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] at the [[University of Guelph]] in [[Guelph]], [[Ontario]], Canada. It is home to the [[Guelph Gryphons]] varsity [[Canadian football|football]] team. It was built in 1970, and has a fixed [[seating capacity]] of approximately 8,500, including fixed seating and the grass hill on the east side of the stadium. On October 27, 2011, it was announced that the stadium would undergo an $18 million expansion and renovation that will bring fixed seating capacity up to 7,500. It was also announced{{when|date=September 2013}} that an eight-lane track would be installed{{when|date=September 2013}} as well as synthetic turf for the field.{{Cite web |url=http://gryphons.ca/sports/2011/10/27/GEN_1027111629.aspx?tab=thestadiumproject&path=fac |title=About the Stadium Project |access-date=2012-02-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415172910/http://gryphons.ca/sports/2011/10/27/GEN_1027111629.aspx?tab=thestadiumproject&path=fac |archive-date=2012-04-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In November 2012, the [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] announced they had reached a [[memorandum of understanding]] with the university to use Alumni Stadium as their temporary home in 2013 while [[Tim Hortons Field]] is constructed. The stadium underwent a temporary expansion to accommodate the [[Canadian Football League|CFL]] team, with seating for approximately 13,000 spectators.{{cite web|title=Tiger-Cats play host to Eskimos in new temporary home in Guelph|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/football/cfl/tiger-cats-play-host-to-eskimos-in-new-temporary-home-in-guelph-1.1318717|work=The Canadian Press|publisher=CBC News|accessdate=September 18, 2013|date=July 7, 2013}} The Tiger-Cats played 9 of 10 home games at Alumni Stadium during their [[2013 Hamilton Tiger-Cats season|2013 season]], including the [[2013 CFL season|2013 East Final]] against the [[Montreal Alouettes]], which they won in overtime 19-16. The Tiger-Cats would eventually go on to be the runners-up of the [[101st Grey Cup]] at [[Mosaic Stadium at Taylor Field]] in [[Regina, Saskatchewan]], thus ending their tenure at Alumni Stadium.{{cite web|title=Roughriders top Ticats to Win 101st Grey Cup at Home|url=https://www.tsn.ca/cfl/story/?id=437442|work=TSN.ca Staff|publisher=TSN|accessdate=November 25, 2013|date=November 24, 2013}} A 8.5 million dollar, 14,000 square foot Football Pavilion addition to Alumni Stadium is planned for completion by December 2016. The new facility will feature a state-of-the-art locker room, players' lounge with kitchen, therapy room with cold and hot tubs, equipment room, coaches offices, meeting rooms and a board room. The two largest meeting rooms and the roof top will double as licensed, game-day viewing areas for alumni. This facility will also allow for better support to football officials and the visiting teams. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|url=http://gryphons.ca/sports/2010/6/27/GEN_0627103600.aspx?tab=facilities}} {{coord|43.5351|N|80.2267|W|display=title}} {{University of Guelph |state=expanded}} {{Hamilton Tiger-Cats}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Guelph]] [[Category:Canadian Football League venues]] [[Category:Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Canada]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Ontario]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ontario]] [[Category:University sports venues in Canada]] [[Category:1970 establishments in Canada]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1970]] [[Category:Canadian football venues]] [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Canada]]

Harvey]] | editing = [[Gordon Pilkington]] | studio = Highbury Productions | distributor = [[General Film Distributors]] | released = 28 February 1949 | runtime = 62 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = [[English language|English]] | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Badger's Green''''' is a 1949 British [[comedy film]] directed by John Irwin and starring [[Barbara Murray]], [[Brian Nissen]], [[Garry Marsh]] and [[Kynaston Reeves]]. It is based on the play ''[[Badger's Green (play)|Badger's Green]]'' by [[R.C. Sheriff]], which had previously been turned into a 1934 [[Badger's Green (1934 film)|film of the same title]]. It was shot at [[Highbury Studios]] and released as a [[second feature]] by the [[Rank Organisation]], on the same bill as ''[[Eureka Stockade (1949 film)|Eureka Stockade]]''.Chibnall & MacFarlane p.290 The film's sets were designed by [[Don Russell (art director)|Don Russell]]. ==Synopsis== A company plans a massive development in the quiet village of Badger's Green, angering the existing inhabitants. It is eventually agreed that the outcome of the dispute will be settled by a local [[cricket]] match. ==Main cast== * [[Barbara Murray]] as Jane Morton * [[Brian Nissen]] as Dickie Wetherby * [[Garry Marsh]] as Major Forrester * [[Kynaston Reeves]] as Doctor Wetherby * [[Laurence Naismith]] as Mr Butler * [[Mary Merrall]] as Mrs Wetherby * Clifford Buckton as Sergeant Foster * [[Stuart Latham]] as PC Percy * [[Lionel Murton]] as Albert * [[Jack McNaughton]] as Mr Twigg * [[Norman Pierce]] as Sam Rogers * Ethel Ramsey as Mrs Rogers * [[Patrick Troughton]] as Jim Carter ==References== ==Bibliography== * Chibnall, Steve & McFarlane, Brian. ''The British 'B' Film''. Palgrave MacMillan, 2009. ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0040145}} [[Category:1949 films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:British films based on plays]] [[Category:1940s comedy films]] [[Category:British comedy films]] [[Category:1940s sports films]] [[Category:British sports films]] [[Category:Films set in England]] [[Category:Films shot at Highbury Studios]] [[Category:Cricket films]] [[Category:British black-and-white films]] {{1940s-UK-comedy-film-stub}} {{sport-film-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Canale Arena| nickname = | image = | location = 650 East Parkway South
[[Memphis, Tennessee]] 38104 | coordinates = {{coord|35.12674|-89.983}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1950 | renovated = December 10, 2004 | expanded = | closed = | owner = [[Christian Brothers University]] | construction_cost = | architect = [[Askew Nixon Ferguson Architects]]{{cite web | url = http://www.anfa.com/project.aspx?id=11&cat=1&i=6 | title = Christian Brothers University, Master Plan | publisher = Askew Nixon Ferguson Architects | accessdate = 2008-05-31 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}| former_names = De La Salle Gymnasium | tenants = [[Christian Brothers University Buccaneers]] | seating_capacity = 1,000| }} '''Canale Arena''' (formerly '''De La Salle Gymnasium''') is the on-campus athletic facility for [[Christian Brothers University]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Tennessee]]. == Buccaneers == {{main|Christian Brothers University Buccaneers}} Canale Arena is home to the [[Buccaneer]] and Lady Buccaneer [[basketball]] and [[volleyball]] teams. The Buccaneer basketball team was the [[Gulf South Conference]] champion in 2008.{{cite web | date= March 9, 2008 | url= http://www.gobucsgo.com/news/2008/3/9/030908aaa_71.aspx?path=mbball | title = Bucs Hold On For First GSC Championship, 93-89 | publisher = Christian Brothers University Athletics | last = Opperman | first = Eric | accessdate = 2008-10-12}} == History == === Origin === The original structure was completed in 1950.{{cite web | url = http://www2.cbu.edu/cbu/AboutCBU/OverviewHistory/chronology/index.htm | title = CBU Chronology | publisher = Christian Brothers University | accessdate = 2008-05-30 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080616030514/http://www2.cbu.edu/cbu/AboutCBU/OverviewHistory/chronology/index.htm# | archive-date = 2008-06-16 | dead-url = yes | df = }} At that time, it was the largest indoor [[arena]] in the city of Memphis.{{cite web | date= December 1, 2004 | url= http://www.cbu.edu/News/Releases/canale.html | title = Canale Family Foundation Provides Lead Gift: CBU to Dedicate Renovated Arena on December 10 | publisher = Christian Brothers University | last = Kerr | first = John | accessdate = 2008-05-29}} === Renovation === The arena was fully renovated in 2004. Among renovations were the addition of new stadium seating, bleachers, a hospitality suite, a Hall of Fame conference room, restrooms, a lobby, and Canale Cafe. The arena has a stated capacity of 1,000. === Namesake === The athletic facility was originally named De La Salle Gymnasium in honor of [[Jean-Baptiste de la Salle|St. John Baptist de la Salle]], the founder of the [[Institute of the Brothers of the Christian Schools|Christian Brothers]]. The Lasallian Christian Brothers, a [[Roman Catholic]] [[religious institute]], founded Christian Brothers University in 1871. When the facility was reopened and blessed on December 10, 2004, it was renamed in honor of John D. Canale, Jr. Memphis businessman John D. Canale, Jr. served on the university's board of trustees from 1970 to 1983 and received the university's prestigious Maurelian Medal in 1994 for his support of and service to the university. Canale's history of contribution to the university includes raising funds in 1949 to build De La Salle Gymnasium. Additionally, Canale donated the funding to build the John Canale Pool on campus in 1986. The pool was named in honor of Canale's father, John D. Canale, Sr., a lifelong supporter of the Christian Brothers and [[valedictorian]] of the Christian Brothers College class of 1891. == References == == External links == * [http://www.gobucsgo.com/photo_gallery.aspx?gallery=2 Photographs of Canale Arena] * [http://www.gobucsgo.com Christian Brothers University Athletics] * [http://www.cbu.edu Christian Brothers University] {{Memphis, Tennessee}} [[Category:Christian Brothers University]] [[Category:Christian Brothers Buccaneers and Lady Buccaneers]] [[Category:1950 establishments in Tennessee]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Tennessee]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Event venues established in 1950]] [[Category:Sports venues in Memphis, Tennessee]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1950]]

runtime: 122:39--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/concussion-film-0 | title=''CONCUSSION'' (12A) | publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=November 2, 2015 | news|url=https://www.filmla.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/2015_film_study_v3_WEB.pdf|title=2015 Feature Film Study|last=McDonald|first=Adrian|date=June 15, 2016|publisher=Film L.A.|access-date=June 16, 2016 |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170810062318/https://www.filmla.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/2015_film_study_v3_WEB.pdf |archivedate=August 10, 2017}}</ref><ref name=BOM/> | gross = $48.6 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=concussion2015.htm |title=Concussion |website=[[Box Office Mojo]] |publisher=[[IMDb]] |accessdate= August 21, 2016}}</ref> }} '''''Concussion''''' is a 2015 American [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[Sports film|sports drama]] film directed and written by [[Peter Landesman]], based on the exposé "Game Brain" by [[Jeanne Marie Laskas]], published in 2009 by ''[[GQ]]'' magazine.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bennet Omalu, Concussions, and the NFL: How One Doctor Changed Football Forever|url=https://www.gq.com/story/nfl-players-brain-dementia-study-memory-concussions|work=[[GQ]]|publisher=[[Condé Nast]]|last=Laskas|first=Jeanne Marie|date=September 14, 2009|accessdate=February 17, 2016}}</ref> Set in 2002, the film stars [[Will Smith]] as [[Bennet Omalu|Dr. Bennet Omalu]], a forensic pathologist who fights against the [[National Football League]] trying to suppress his research on [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]] (CTE) brain degeneration suffered by professional football players. It also stars [[Alec Baldwin]], [[Gugu Mbatha-Raw]], and [[Albert Brooks]].
The film premiered at [[American Film Institute|AFI Fest]] on November 11, 2015 and was released by [[Columbia Pictures]] on December 25, 2015. The film grossed $48 million worldwide and received mixed reviews, although Smith earned a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama|Golden Globe]] nomination.
==Plot==
[[Steelers]] center [[Mike Webster]] is found dead in his pickup truck, after years of self-mutilation and homelessness. Before his death, a fellow [[American Football|football]] player, [[Justin Strzelczyk]], comes to him, and confides that he is starting to lose his memory, that he is saying odd things to his children, and nearly threw his wife against the wall. A disoriented Webster brushes the worries off, and deliriously tells him that the most important thing "is to finish the game," which is what he said during his Hall of Fame speech.
[[Bennet Omalu]], a [[Forensic pathology|forensic pathologist]] with the [[Allegheny County, Pennsylvania]] [[coroner]]'s office, handles Webster's [[autopsy]]. He wonders how a man, otherwise healthy, and fairly young, could have degenerated so quickly, and makes it a point to figure out why he died of a heart attack at only fifty. Omalu closely examines microscope slides of Webster's brain and discovers that he had severe brain damage. He ultimately determines that Webster died as a result of the long-term effects of repeated blows to the head, a disorder he later calls [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]] (CTE). With the help of former Steelers team doctor Julian Bailes, fellow [[Neurology|neurologist]] [[Steven T. DeKosky]] and county coroner [[Cyril Wecht]], Omalu publishes a paper on his findings, which is initially dismissed by the [[National Football League|NFL]].
Over the next few years, Omalu discovers that three other former NFL players, Strzelczyk (died 2004), [[Terry Long (American football)|Terry Long]] (died 2005), and [[Andre Waters]] (died 2006), had symptoms very similar to Webster's. He finally persuades newly appointed NFL commissioner [[Roger Goodell]] to allow him to present his findings before a committee on player safety. However, the NFL does not take him seriously, and he is barred from the committee meeting, forcing Bailes, a former NFL employee, to give the presentation in his place. However, the meeting is a set up, where the NFL claims that the players' head trauma was due to past injuries, having nothing to do with football. As he leaves the meeting, former [[National Football League Players Association|NFL Players Association]] executive [[Dave Duerson]] angrily confronts Omalu and tells him to "go back to [[Africa]]."
Omalu is subjected to considerable pressure to back down from his efforts, as football is a widely beloved sport in Pittsburgh, having provided jobs and allowed men to go to college. Wecht is subjected to a politically motivated prosecution on corruption charges, and Omalu is forced to leave Pittsburgh soon after, lest he be deported, or sent to prison on petty charges as punishment for tarnishing the NFL. Before leaving he urges the NFL to tell the truth. Omalu's wife, Prema, suffers a [[miscarriage]] after being stalked. The Omalus are forced to leave their dream home outside Pittsburgh. They move to [[Lodi, California]], where Omalu takes a job with the [[San Joaquin County, California|San Joaquin County]] coroner's office.
Three years later, Omalu is vindicated when Duerson commits suicide due to growing cognitive problems. In his suicide note, Duerson admits that Omalu was right. Omalu is allowed to address an NFLPA conference on concussions and CTE. He informs them that he once wished he had never known Mike Webster, but by knowing him, he has the responsibility to inform NFL players of the true risks that they take by playing. He says that he holds no resentment for the NFL and tells them to forgive themselves and be at peace. Amid growing scrutiny from [[United States Congress|Congress]], the NFL is forced to take the concussion issue more seriously, and in 2011, [[2011 NFL lockout|NFL players sue the league]] for not properly informing them of the risk of CTE. Omalu is offered a job as chief medical examiner for the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]], but as explained in closing title cards, turns it down, remaining with Prema and their two children in California, where he became a U.S. citizen in February 2015.
==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Will Smith]] as [[Bennet Omalu]] * [[Alec Baldwin]] as Julian Bailes * [[Albert Brooks]] as [[Cyril Wecht]] * [[Gugu Mbatha-Raw]] as Prema Mutiso * [[David Morse (actor)|David Morse]] as [[Mike Webster]] * [[Arliss Howard]] as [[Joseph Maroon]] * [[Mike O'Malley]] as Daniel Sullivan * [[Eddie Marsan]] as [[Steven T. DeKosky]] * [[Hill Harper]] as Christopher Jones * [[Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje]] as [[Dave Duerson]] * [[Stephen Moyer]] as Ron Hamilton * [[Richard T. Jones]] as [[Andre Waters]] * [[Paul Reiser]] as Elliot Pellman * [[Luke Wilson]] as [[Roger Goodell]] * [[Sara Lindsey]] as Gracie * [[Matt Willig|Matthew Willig]] as [[Justin Strzelczyk]] * [[Bitsie Tulloch]] as Keana Strzelczyk * Eme Ikwuakor as [[Amobi Okoye]] * [[Phillip Chorba]] as the technician {{div col end}}
==Production==
===Development=== [[Ridley Scott]]'s idea of an NFL concussion film was inspired by Dr. Bennett Omalu's study about former NFL stars [[Junior Seau]] and [[Dave Duerson]], both of whom committed suicide after suffering from [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]] (CTE). Scott was set to direct after his film ''[[Exodus: Gods and Kings]]'', while he and Facio were looking for an A-list writer.<ref name=Concussions>{{cite news|last1=Fleming|first1=Mike Jr.|title=Ridley Scott To Direct Film About Deadly Effects Of Concussions In Football Players|url=http://deadline.com/2013/11/ridley-scott-to-direct-film-about-deadly-effects-of-concussions-in-football-players-630082/|accessdate=October 12, 2014|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=November 7, 2013}}</ref> In November and December 2013, two more NFL concussion films were in development, first ''Game Time Decision'' with writer/director and former NFL training camp attendee [[wide receiver]] Matthew A. Cherry and actor [[Isaiah Washington]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fleming|first1=Mike Jr.|title=Isaiah Washington, Matthew Cherry Huddle On Football Concussion Pic|url=http://deadline.com/2013/11/isaiah-washington-matthew-cherry-huddle-on-football-concussion-pic-634239/|accessdate=October 12, 2014|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=November 13, 2013}}</ref> and another film ''[[League of Denial]]'' with producers [[Walter Parkes]] and [[Laurie MacDonald]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fleming|first1=Mike Jr.|title=A Collision Of Football Concussion Projects: Parkes/MacDonald Options NFL Head Injury Expose ‘League Of Denial’ For Pic|url=http://deadline.com/2013/12/a-collision-of-football-concussion-projects-parkesmacdonald-options-nfl-head-injury-expose-league-of-denial-for-pic-648245/|accessdate=October 12, 2014|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=December 9, 2013}}</ref> Landesman had based his script on the 2009 [[GQ]] article ''Game Brain'' by [[Jeanne Marie Laskas]].<ref name=Landesman-Sony>{{cite news|last1=Fleming|first1=Mike Jr.|title=Will Smith Eyeing Gridiron Concussion Pic At Sony With Peter Landesman Directing|url=http://deadline.com/2014/06/will-smith-eyeing-gridiron-concussion-pic-739681/|accessdate=October 12, 2014|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=June 3, 2014}}</ref> Smith and Marsan previously appeared together in the 2008 [[superhero film]] ''[[Hancock (film)|Hancock]]''. It received $14.4 million in film tax credits from [[Pennsylvania]].{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] started on October 27, 2014, in [[Pittsburgh|Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], and filmed there through mid-January. One of the film's key scenes was shot in Altius Restaurant in the [[Mount Washington (Pittsburgh)|Mt. Washington]] section of Pittsburgh. Other area scenes were shot at a church in Pittsburgh's [[Hill District]], the [[Carnegie Free Library of Braddock|Braddock Carnegie Library]],<ref>{{cite news|title=The Will Smith crew filmed at Braddock Carnegie Library this week|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/movies/2014/12/04/The-Will-Smith-film-continued-production-at-Braddock-Carnegie-Library-this-week/stories/201412040306|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |author=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date=December 4, 2014|accessdate=July 11, 2018|publisher=PG Publishing}}</ref> and in [[downtown Pittsburgh]].<ref name="Vancheri">{{cite web |first= Barbara |last=Vancheri |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/movies/2014/10/31/Will-Smith-movie-shooting-around-town/stories/201410310038|title=Will Smith football movie shooting in Pittsburgh|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|date=October 31, 2014|accessdate=July 11, 2018|publisher=PG Publishing}}</ref>
===Music=== [[James Newton Howard]] composed the score for the film. [[Klayton]] (frontman of [[Celldweller]]) provided synth programming for the score.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/celldweller/posts/10153595624591672|author=[[Klayton]]|publisher=[[Facebook]]|work=[[Celldweller]] official page |date=August 31, 2015|title=By now, most of you have heard that there's a new Will Smith movie called "Concussion" coming out. Some of you probably know that it's being scored by James Newton Howard.|accessdate=August 31, 2015}}</ref> R&B singer [[Leon Bridges]] provided a new song, called "So Long".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/in-contention/leon-bridges-so-long-concussion-will-smith-nfl-1201620991/|title='Concussion': Leon Bridges Writes Song for Will Smith Drama|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=October 19, 2015|first=Kristopher|last=Tapley|accessdate=July 11, 2018}}</ref>
==Release== The first [[Trailer (promotion)|trailer]] was released on YouTube on August 31, 2015 by Sony Pictures Entertainment.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Sony Pictures Entertainment]]|title=Concussion - Official Trailer (2015) - Will Smith|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Io6hPdC41RM|accessdate=August 31, 2015|publisher=[[YouTube]]|date=August 31, 2015}}</ref> Sony released the film on December 25, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNary|first1=Dave|title=Will Smith’s ‘Concussion’ Drama Set for Christmas Release|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/will-smiths-concussion-drama-set-for-christmas-release-1201416809/|accessdate=January 28, 2015|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=January 27, 2015}}</ref> Marketing included advertisements for the film airing during NFL games.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chase|first1=Chris|title=The NFL-shaming 'Concussion' aired a commercial during Thanksgiving game|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2015/11/concussion-trailer-will-smith-thanksgiving-nfl-game-detroit-philadelphia-allowed-to-air-during-nfl-games|accessdate=December 2, 2015|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|work=[[USA Today]]|date=November 26, 2015}}</ref>
''Concussion'' was released on [[Digital distribution|Digital HD]] on March 15, 2016, before being released two weeks later on [[DVD]], [[Blu-ray]] and 4K Ultra HD on March 29, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdsreleasedates.com/movies/7690/concussion|title=Concussion (2015)|publisher=DVDs Release Dates|accessdate=February 9, 2016}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Box office=== ''Concussion'' grossed $34.5 million in North America and $14.1 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $48.6 million, against a budget of $35 million.<ref name=BOM />
In the United States and Canada, the film opened on December 25, 2015 alongside ''[[Daddy's Home (film)|Daddy's Home]]'', ''[[Joy (film)|Joy]]'', ''[[Point Break (2015 film)|Point Break]]'' and the [[Wide release|nationwide expansion]] of ''[[The Big Short (film)|The Big Short]]''. In its opening weekend, the film was projected to gross $8–10 million from 2,841 theaters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/12/star-wars-force-awakens-christmas-box-office-joy-daddys-home-concussion-point-break-1201670872/|title=‘Force Awakens’ Will Own Christmas Weekend As Five Wide Releases Join The Fray – Box Office Preview|first=Anthony |last=D'Alessandro|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=December 21, 2015|accessdate=December 23, 2015}}</ref> It eventually grossed $10.5 million, finishing 7th at the box office.<ref name=CinemaScore/> Due to Smith's star status and the $35 million production budget, the film was considered a box office disappointment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/shadowandact/concussion-adds-to-will-smiths-growing-list-of-recent-box-office-disappointments-whats-going-on-20160111|title='Concussion' adds to Will Smith's recent list of box office disappointments. What's going on?|first=Tambay|last=Obenson|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|work=[[IndieWire]]|date=January 11, 2016|accessdate=February 9, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsworldnews.com/articles/55400/20151226/concussion-movie-update-low-box-office-numbers-proves-people-arent-really-concerned-about-cte-video.htm|title=Concussion Movie Update: Low box office numbers prove people aren't really concerned about CTE|first=Eduardo|last=Mendez|work=Sports World News|date=December 26, 2015|accessdate=February 9, 2016}}</ref>
===Critical response=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 59% based on 192 reviews, with an average rating of 6.1/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "''Concussion'' lands a solid, well-acted hit on its impressively timely subject matter, even if its traditional, sports drama structure is a little too safe to deserve a full-on dance in the end zone."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/concussion_2015/ |title=Concussion (2015) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media]] |accessdate=July 11, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 55 out of 100, based on 39 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/concussion-2015 |title=Concussion Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=February 12, 2016}}</ref> On [[CinemaScore]], audiences gave the film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="CinemaScore">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/12/star-wars-force-awakens-christmas-weekend-box-office-record-joy-daddys-home-concussion-point-break-1201672899/ |title=‘Daddy’, ‘Joy’ & ‘Hateful Eight’ Reap Fortune As ‘Star Wars’ Halo Effect Impacts B.O... Can ‘Force Awakens’ Hit $1 Billion In U.S.? |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |accessdate=July 11, 2018 |first1=Anthony |last1=D'Alessandro |first2=Anita |last2=Busch |date=December 28, 2015}}</ref>
Will Smith's performance was praised for being "sensitive [and] understated" by ''[[The Denver Post]]'', while [[Alec Baldwin]]'s accent was a subject of ridicule.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.denverpost.com/movies/ci_29312021/concussion-movie-review-sensitive-will-smith-anchors-film |title="Concussion" movie review: A sensitive Will Smith anchors film that hits home |date=December 25, 2015 |author=[[The Associated Press]] |website=[[The Denver Post]] |publisher=[[Digital First Media]] |accessdate=January 20, 2016}}</ref>
===Accolades=== {|class="wikitable sortable" width="95%" ! colspan="5" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | Awards |-style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! Award ! Category ! Recipient(s) and nominee(s) ! Result |- | [[African-American Film Critics Association]] | Best Actor | [[Will Smith]] | {{won}} |- | rowspan="4" | [[Black Reel Awards]] | Outstanding Actor, Motion Picture | Will Smith | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Motion Picture |''Concussion'' | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Supporting Actress, Motion Picture | [[Gugu Mbatha-Raw]] | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Ensembles | | {{nom}} |- | [[73rd Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]] | [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actor – Drama]] | Will Smith | {{nominated}} |- | [[Hollywood Film Awards]] | Actor of the Year | Will Smith | {{won}} |- | rowspan="2" | [[2016 MTV Movie Awards|MTV Movie Awards]] | Best Male Performance | Will Smith | {{nom}} |- | True Story | | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="3" | [[NAACP Image Award]]s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naacpimageawards.net/main_winners_nominees.html|title=Nominees|work=47th NACCP Image Awards|publisher=[[NAACP Image Award]]s|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160828102253/http://www.naacpimageawards.net/main_winners_nominees.html|archivedate=August 28, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> | [[NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Motion Picture|Outstanding Motion Picture]] |''Concussion'' | {{nom}} |- | [[NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Actor in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Actor in a Motion Picture]] | Will Smith | {{nom}} |- | [[NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Motion Picture]] | Gugu Mbatha-Raw | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2" |[[Palm Springs International Film Festival]] | Creative Impact in Acting Award | Will Smith | {{won}} |- | Directors to Watch | [[Peter Landesman]] | {{won}} |- | [[20th Satellite Awards|Satellite Awards]] | Best Actor | Will Smith | {{nom}} |}
==Controversy== Family members of [[Dave Duerson]], a former NFL player who suffered from CTE (chronic traumatic encephalopathy), claimed the film portrayed Duerson in a bad light. In one scene, Duerson's character called Omalu's character a "quack" in addition to telling him "to go back to Africa" and "get away from our game."<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|title = Dave Duerson’s Family Says ‘Concussion’ Film Smears Him|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/17/sports/football/concussion-movie-smears-dave-duerson-his-family-says.html|newspaper = [[The New York Times]]|publisher=The New York Times Company|date = December 16, 2015|access-date = December 17, 2015|first = Ken|last = Belson}}</ref> In another scene, Duerson is shown mocking former NFL player [[Andre Waters]] when he filed an application for benefits in connection with head injuries he sustained while playing in the NFL. Duerson's family members called these scenes false. In response, Landesman, the film's director, stated that the film was "emotionally and spiritually accurate all the way through".<ref name=":0"/>
''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' science writer Daniel Engber, who has been skeptical of the link between CTE and the deaths of players found to have had it,<ref name="Engber Seau article">{{cite news|last=Engber|first=Daniel|title=The Concussion Panic|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/science/2012/05/junior_seau_s_suicide_are_concussions_responsible_.html|newspaper=[[Slate (website)|Slate]]|publisher=The Slate Group|date=May 9, 2012|access-date=April 22, 2016}}</ref> called the film inaccurate in other ways, for example suggesting that Wecht's arrest on corruption charges was motivated by Omalu's paper, when in fact it was published three months afterwards. "[The film] feeds into a pervasive myth at the center of the national discussion over football and head injuries," he charges.<ref name="Engber criticism">{{cite web|last1=Engber|first1=Daniel|title=Concussion Lies|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/sports_nut/2015/12/the_truth_about_will_smith_s_concussion_and_bennet_omalu.html|newspaper=[[Slate (website)|Slate]]|publisher=The Slate Group|accessdate=December 26, 2015|date=December 21, 2015}}</ref> In particular, he cites a 2012 [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]] study<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Baron|first1=Sherry L.|last2=Hein|first2=Misty J.|last3=Lehman|first3=Everett|last4=Gersic|first4=Christine M.|title=Body Mass Index, Playing Position, Race, and the Cardiovascular Mortality of Retired Professional Football Players|journal=[[American Journal of Cardiology]]|date=March 15, 2012|volume=109|issue=6|pages=889–896|url=http://www.ajconline.org/article/S0002-9149(11)03387-X/fulltext|accessdate=December 26, 2015|doi=10.1016/j.amjcard.2011.10.050}}</ref> indicating that football players, on average compared to the population as a whole, live longer and generally healthier lives, though the study also indicates, as Engber concedes, that former football players are also more likely to suffer, and die, from neurodegenerative disease.<ref name="Engber criticism" />
More recent research and thinking also looks at the steady accumulation of subconcussive blows, in addition to symptomatic concussions, as a major contribution factor in the development of CTE.<ref>[https://www.bu.edu/sph/2018/01/18/hits-not-concussions-cause-cte/ Hits, Not Concussions, Cause CTE], Boston University School of Public, Jan. 18, 2018.</ref><ref>[https://www.menshealth.com/health/a21346159/should-kids-play-football/ We Know Football Is Dangerous. So Why Are We Still Letting Our Sons Play It?], ''Men's Health'', Andrew Lawrence, July 10, 2018.</ref> For example, a 2018 study found that each year an athlete played tackle football before age 12 predicted earlier onset of CTE symptoms by an average of two-and-a half-years, but not symptom severity. These CTE symptoms include cognitive, behavioral, and mood problems.<ref name="Study finds youth football tied to earlier symptoms of CTE, ESPN, April 30, 2018">[http://www.espn.com/moresports/story/_/id/23367461/study-finds-youth-football-tied-earlier-cte "Study finds youth football tied to earlier symptoms of CTE,"] ESPN, April 30, 2018.</ref><ref name="Annals of Neurology, 30 April 2018">[https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/ana.25245 Age of First Exposure to Tackle Football and Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy], ''Annals of Neurology'', Michael L. Alosco PhD, Jesse Mez MD, MS, et al., April 30, 2018.</ref>

Center Field – 410
Right Field – 350 }} '''Dehler Park''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Billings, Montana]]. It is primarily used for [[baseball]] and is the home of the [[Billings Mustangs]] in the [[Pioneer Baseball League|Pioneer League]]. It is also the home field of the [[Montana State University Billings]] Yellowjackets.{{cite web|last1=Uken|first1=Cindy|title=8 years later, baseball fans still herald presence of $13.7 million Dehler Park|url=http://billingsgazette.com/news/local/years-later-baseball-fans-still-herald-presence-of-million-dehler/article_ce4bff08-c2e0-571a-8924-b03b11dc42e5.html|website=BillingsGazette.com|publisher=The Billings Gazette|accessdate=30 September 2015}} The ballpark opened on June 29, 2008 and has a capacity of 3,071 people (6,000 including standing room only). It replaced [[Cobb Field]] which was a fixture in Billings since the 1930s. The groundbreaking ceremony took place March 22, 2007.{{cite web|title=Officials Break Ground on New Billings Ballpark|url=http://billings.mustangs.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20070322&content_id=194759&vkey=news_t513&fext=.jsp&sid=t513|publisher=Billings Mustangs|date=March 22, 2007|accessdate=July 4, 2007}} [[File:Firstpitchatdehler.gif|thumbnail|left|125px|First pitch, June 29, 2008]]The stadium was named by Billings businessman Jon Dehler, who purchased the naming rights in 2007 to honor his father, Billy Joe Dehler.{{cite news |title=Patron of the Game|url=http://www.helenair.com/articles/2008/03/01/local/top/50lo_030108_baseball.txt|newspaper=[[Independent Record|Helena Independent Record]]|date=March 1, 2008|accessdate=July 17, 2008}} The park still has part of Cobb Field included, as a section down the right field line includes some of the same bench seating used at the old stadium. Outside of that and the over 2,500+ individual seats are two grass berm areas for picnic seating. Patrons can walk around the entire field thanks to an outfield terrace, which is also home to those who buy a standing room-only ticket. Theoretically the stadium could feasibly hold well over 6,000 people with a large standing room-only crowd. The first event at the stadium was on June 29, 2008, an [[American Legion#1920s|American Legion baseball]] game between the Billings Scarlets and Bozeman Bucks. The Bucks led 10–3 when the game was suspended after seven innings due to malfunctions with the lights. It was completed at [[Pirtz Field]], the local Legion Ballpark, the following night with the Bucks winning 16–3.{{cite news|title=Scarlets Earn Split with Bozeman |url=http://billingsgazette.net/articles/2008/07/01/sports/local/62-prepscarlets.txt |newspaper=[[Billings Gazette]] |date=July 1, 2008 |accessdate=July 2, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The first [[home run]], hit by Matt Comer of the Bucks, was retrieved by a man riding a bicycle outside the stadium. After some speculation as to what would become of the ball, the owner of the ball came forth and agreed to donate the ball to the Billings Parks and Recreation Department for a Dehler Park Hall of Fame display.{{cite news|title=Dehler Park's First Home Run Ball |first=Ed |last=Kemmick |url=http://billingsgazette.net/articles/2008/07/02/news/local/20-firstball.txt |newspaper=[[Billings Gazette]] |date=July 2, 2008 |accessdate=July 2, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On June 30 the park hosted local [[Little League]] championship games before the [[Billings Mustangs]] and [[Great Falls Voyagers]] met in the first professional baseball game at the park on July 1.{{cite web|title=Play Ball! Don't Miss the Grand Opening of Dehler Park |url=http://www.prpl.info/pdfs/Brochure%20SWF/PBC.swf |publisher=Billings Parks & Recreation |accessdate=June 17, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721231617/http://www.prpl.info/pdfs/Brochure%20SWF/PBC.swf |archivedate=July 21, 2011 |df= }} The Mustangs won a rain-soaked 9–7 game highlighted by a Michael Konstanty [[grand slam (baseball)|grand slam]] which stands as the first professional homer at the field. Attendance for the game was 3,749.{{cite news |title=Fans soak up Mustangs game|first=Zach|last=Benoit|url=http://billingsgazette.com/news/local/fans-soak-up-mustangs-game/article_9ba1e339-3257-522f-8a0b-858c48224077.html|newspaper=[[Billings Gazette]]|date=July 1, 2008|accessdate=June 5, 2014}} ==Notable performers== Other uses for the stadium include concerts and plays. Some of the most notable performers at Dehler Park include: *[[Bob Dylan]] and [[John Mellencamp]] – August 11, 2010 ==References== {{reflist|1}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?ymd=20060308&content_id=41115662&fext=.jsp&vkey=news_t513&sid=t513 Billings Mustangs – Dehler Park] *[http://www.msubsports.com/sports/2010/8/30/BB_0830105131.aspx Montana State University Billings Yellowjackets Athletics – Dehler Park] *[http://www.billingsparks.org/park/dehler/ Billings Parks & Recreation – Dehler Park] {{Pioneer_League_Ballparks}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Montana]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Billings, Montana]] [[Category:Montana State Billings Yellowjackets baseball]] [[Category:2008 establishments in Montana]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2008]]

{{Infobox national sports federations |assocname= Egyptian Handball Federation
''{{lang-ar|اتحاد كرة اليد المصري}}'' |abbrev= EHF |logo= Egyptian Handball Federation (logo).png |logosize= 300px |countryflag= Egypt |iocnation= Arab Republic of Egypt |url= www.ehf.com.eg |sport= [[Handball]] |othersport1= [[Beach Handball]] |othersport2= [[Wheelchair Handball]] |historytitle=HISTORY |precedingorganisationsname= |yearfounded= {{Start date and age|1957| | |df=y}} |formernames= |demographicstitle=DEMOGRAPHICS |noofclubs= |noofaffclubs= |membershipsize= |participationlevels= |affliationstitle=AFFLIATIONS |IF = [[International Handball Federation]] | IF_abbr = IHF | IF_joined = 1960 |nationalolympiccom= [[Egyptian Olympic Committee]] |continentalassoc= [[African Handball Confederation]] |nocyearjoined= |otheraff2= [[Mediterranean Handball Confederation]] |otheraff3= |otheraff4= |otheraff5= |electedtitle= GOVERNING BODY |patron= |president= Prof. Dr. Mohamed Khaled Abdel Kader Hammouda {{flagicon|EGY}} |sectitle= HEADQUARTERS |address1= El Estade El Bahary, [[Nasr City]], [[Cairo]] |country= [[Egypt]] |chiefexec= |secretarygeneral= |financetitle=FINANCE |companystatus= |operatingincome= |sponsors= }} The '''Egyptian Handball Federation''' ('''EHF''') (''{{lang-ar|اتحاد كرة اليد المصري}}'') is the governing body of [[handball]] and [[beach handball]] in [[Egypt]]. EHF was founded in 1957, joined [[International Handball Federation]] in 1960 and [[African Handball Confederation]] in 1973. EHF is also affiliated to the [[Egyptian Olympic Committee]]. It is based in [[Cairo]].{{cite web|url=http://ihf.info/TheIHF/ContinentalFederations/ConfederationAfricainedeHandball(CAHB)/ListofFederations/EgyptianHandballFederation.aspx|title=Profile at IHF website|date=9 August 2017|work=ihf.info}} ==Competitions== * [[Egyptian Handball League]] ==National teams== * [[Egypt national handball team]] * [[Egypt national junior handball team]] * [[Egypt national youth handball team]] * [[Egypt women's national handball team]] * [[Egypt women's junior national handball team]] * [[Egypt women's youth national handball team]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ehf.com.eg/ Official website] *[http://ihf.info/TheIHF/ContinentalFederations/ConfederationAfricainedeHandball(CAHB)/ListofFederations/EgyptianHandballFederation.aspx Egyptian Handball Federation] at IHF site [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Egypt|Handball]] [[Category:Handball in Egypt]] [[Category:1957 establishments in Egypt]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1957]] [[Category:Handball governing bodies]] {{Sports governing bodies in Egypt}} {{Handball in Egypt}} {{National Members of the International Handball Federation}} {{Handball-stub}} {{Egypt-sport-stub}}

Primeiro de Agosto|Primeiro de Agosto]]
[[Atlético Petróleos Luanda|Petro de Luanda]]
[[S.L. Benfica (Luanda)|Benfica de Luanda]]
[[Angola national football team]] }} The '''Estádio 11 de Novembro''' is a multi-use stadium in [[Luanda]], [[Angola]]. Completed in 2010 ahead of the [[2010 Africa Cup of Nations]], it hosted nine matches during the tournament, including five Group A matches, one group b match, one quarter final, one semi-final, and the final. ==Overview== It is currently used on a regular basis by football clubs [[C.D. Primeiro de Agosto|Primeiro de Agosto]], [[Atlético Petróleos de Luanda|Petro de Luanda]] and [[S.L. Benfica (Luanda)|Benfica de Luanda]] who play in [[Girabola]]. Its capacity is 48,000. The stadium is named after the date of Angola's independence. The statium is located in [[Belas, Luanda, Angola|Belas]] municipality at the Expressway surrounding Luanda on the road side. ==1º de Agosto vs TP Mazembe post-match incident== Five people were reportedly killed after the 45.000 capacity crowd match on Saturday 15th September 2018, including two children who were trampled and/or suffocated to death while exiting the stadium. Before the match begun, supporters called a radio station urging the organization to open all gates after the match ended for fear of a tragedy and after going through similar ordeals in the past. The Angolan Ministry of Youth and Sports in a statement regreted the incident, expressed condolences to the relatives and vowed to launch an investigation. On their part, the club's management promised to assist the relatives in funeral expenses.{{cite web |url=http://www.angop.ao/angola/en_us/noticias/desporto/2018/8/38/Football-Sports-ministry-regrets-stadium-stampede,6b10dda3-93a7-4029-a245-977cfd549c21.html |title=Football: Sports ministry regrets stadium stampede |publisher=ANGOP Angolan News Agency|date=17 Sep 2018 |accessdate= 17 Sep 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://www.angop.ao/angola/pt_pt/noticias/desporto/2018/8/38/Futebol-MINJUD-lamenta-tragedia-estadio-Novembro,4f821296-2cd6-41f1-9b9e-4dc4a9a184cd.html |title=Futebol: MINJUD lamenta tragédia no estádio 11 de Novembro |publisher=ANGOP Angolan News Agency|date=17 Sep 2018 |accessdate= 17 Sep 2018 |language=pt}}{{cite web |url=http://www.primeiroagosto.com/index.php/component/k2/item/4404-nota-de-condol%C3%AAncia |title=Nota de condolência |publisher=primeiroagosto.com|date=14 Sep 2018 |accessdate= 17 Sep 2018 |language=pt}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Estadio 11 de Novembro|'''Estádio 11 de Novembro'''}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091219103619/http://www.can2010angola.com/welwitchia_stadium.php Venue information {{pt icon}}] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091225052039/http://www.can-angola2010.com/Estadios/Cidades/Luanda/CAN_002296 Stadium information] *[http://www.fussballtempel.net/caf/ANG/11_Novembro.html Photographs of the stadium] {{s-start}} {{succession box | | title = [[Africa Cup of Nations]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Fazanerija | nickname = | image = Mura v Domzale 2012.jpg | image_size = 285px | fullname = Mestni stadion Fazanerija | location = [[Murska Sobota]], [[Slovenia]] | coordinates = {{coord|46|40|6|N|16|9|27|E|display=it|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = 1934 | built = 1983 | opened = | renovated = 2001 | expanded = 1994 | record_attendance = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Municipality of Murska Sobota | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[NK Mura]] (–2005)
[[ND Mura 05]] (2005–2013)
[[NŠ Mura]] (2013–present) | seating_capacity = 3,782 | dimensions = 105 × 68 metres | scoreboard = }} '''Fazanerija City Stadium''' ({{lang-sl|Mestni stadion Fazanerija}}) is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Murska Sobota]], [[Slovenia]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home ground of [[NŠ Mura]]. The stadium was built in 1983 and has a capacity of 3,782 covered seats. With the standing area included the total capacity of the stadium is around 5,500. ==History== The first football pitch in the area was built in 1934 and it was not until 1983 when the first stand was built. Great results and attendances on NK Mura matches were the main factors leading club officials to build two additional stands in 1994. The stadium got its present image in 2001 when the stands where covered by a roof. The current capacity of the stadium is 3,782 covered seats. With the standing area included the stadium could hold up to 5,500 people for important club matches. ==Football== The stadium is mainly used for football and is the home ground of football club [[NŠ Mura]]. Previously, the stadium was used by [[NK Mura]] and [[ND Mura 05]], the clubs that were dissolved in 2005 and 2013, respectively. So far, the stadium has hosted two matches of the [[Slovenia national football team]] and was part of two [[Slovenian Football Cup|Slovenian Cup]] finals. In 2011, the stadium was used by the [[Football Association of Slovenia]] as one of the main venues for hosting the youth tournaments for U17 and U19 national teams.{{cite web | url = http://www.nogomania.com/Slovenski-Nogomet/Novica/Zacetek-kvalifikacij-U19.aspx | title = Začetek kvalifikacij U19 | publisher = Nogomania | accessdate = 6 February 2011 | language = Slovenian }} ===Slovenian Cup finals=== {| class="wikitable" !Date !Competition !Home !Away !Result !Attendance |- |8 June 1994 |[[1993–94 Slovenian Cup|Slovenian Cup]] |[[NK Mura|Mura]] |[[NK Maribor|Maribor]] |1–01 |4,500 |- |24 May 1995 |[[1994–95 Slovenian Cup|Slovenian Cup]] |[[NK Mura|Mura]] |[[NK Celje|Celje]] |1–02 |3,000 |} 11st leg; 22nd leg ===National team matches=== {| class="wikitable" !Date !Competition !Country !Result !Attendance |- |22 April 1998 |Friendly |{{fb|Czech Republic}} |1–3 |2,000 |- |20 August 2003 |Friendly |{{fb|Hungary}} |2–1 |4,500 |} ==See also== *[[List of football stadiums in Slovenia]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.stadioni.org/murska_sobota/mestni_stadion_fazanerija Mestni stadion Fazanerija] at Football Stadiums of Slovenia {{Slovenian PrvaLiga stadiums}} [[Category:Football venues in Slovenia]] [[Category:NK Mura|Stadium]] [[Category:Murska Sobota]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Slovenia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1983]] [[Category:1983 establishments in Slovenia]] [[Category:ND Mura 05|Stadium]]

{{Infobox stadium | image = [[Image:FoleyFieldDugout.jpg|250px|Foley Field from behind the dugout at the University of Georgia in Athens, Georgia]] | caption = Foley Field in Athens, Georgia | stadium_name = Foley Field | location = [[Athens, Georgia]] | coordinates = {{coord|33|56|27|N|83|22|49|W|type:landmark|display=inline, title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1966 | renovated = 2015 | owner = [[University of Georgia]] | operator = [[University of Georgia]] | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = [[Georgia Bulldogs baseball]] (1966–present)
[[Southeastern Conference Baseball Tournament|Southeastern Conference Tournament]]: 1987
'''NCAA Regional:''' 2001, 2004, 2006, 2008, 2018 | dimensions = | seating_capacity = 3,291 (seated) }} '''Foley Field''' is a [[baseball]] [[stadium]] in [[Athens, Georgia]], [[United States]]. It is the home field of the [[University of Georgia]] Bulldogs [[college baseball]] team. The stadium holds 3,291 people. Foley Field was built in 1966. The stadium was renovated in 1990, the same year that the University of Georgia won the College World Series in Omaha, Nebraska. Since that renovation, Georgia owns a 378–193–1 (.660) record there (through the 2006 season). Foley Field hosted the [[1987 Southeastern Conference Baseball Tournament]], won by [[Mississippi State Bulldogs baseball|Mississippi State]]. More recently, Foley Field has hosted four NCAA regional tournaments in 2001, 2004, 2006, 2008, and in 2018. In all four years, the Bulldogs' baseball team advanced to the College World Series. Super Regionals were also hosted in 2001 featuring Florida State University, in 2006 against the University of South Carolina, and in 2008 with North Carolina State University as the guest. All three super regionals were won by Georgia, two games to one. The Bulldogs own a record of 20–7 in NCAA post season games held at Foley Field. They also set a 16–0 mark in elimination games with a 17–8 win on June 8, 2008 to earn a trip to [[Johnny Rosenblatt Stadium]]. Several attendance records have been set in recent years, including in both Super Regionals hosted by the stadium. First, 7th-ranked Georgia defeated 10th-ranked [[Florida State Seminoles baseball|Florida State]] 8-7 in front of 4,290 spectators on June 2, 2001. Then, on June 12, 2006, 6th-ranked Georgia defeated 15th-ranked [[South Carolina Gamecocks baseball|South Carolina]] in front of 4,302 spectators. The most recent record set was during the regular season on March 21, 2009, as 3rd-ranked Georgia defeated [[Mississippi State Bulldogs baseball|Mississippi State]] 4–0 in front of 4,461 spectators. In 2013, the Bulldogs ranked 35th among [[List of NCAA Division I baseball programs|Division I baseball programs]] in attendance, averaging 1,940 per home game.{{cite web |last=Cutler |first=Tami |title=2013 Division I Baseball Attendance - Final Report |url=http://www.sportswriters.net/ncbwa/news/2013/attendance130611.pdf |publisher=Sportswriters.net |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IGG6kpVy?url=http://www.sportswriters.net/ncbwa/news/2013/attendance130611.pdf |archivedate=July 20, 2013 |date=June 11, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=83cXyR97has Video Tour of Foley Field] *[https://www.sports.uga.edu/ University of Georgia Athletics] UGA official Athletic dept *[http://www.georgiadogs.com/ GeorgiaDogs.com] official UGA sports site {{Georgia Bulldogs baseball navbox}} {{University of Georgia}} {{Southeastern Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{Georgia NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Georgia Bulldogs baseball venues]] [[Category:University of Georgia campus]] [[Category:1966 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1966]] {{GeorgiaUS-baseball-venue-stub}} {{UGeorgia-stub}}

937 Phillips Lane
Louisville, KY 40209| broke_ground = | opened = 1956| closed = | demolished = |Never owner = [[Kentucky State Fair Board]]| operator = [[Kentucky State Fair Board]]| surface = | construction_cost= | architect = | former_names = | website = http://www.kyfairexpo.org/ | tenants = [[Louisville Cardinals men's basketball]] ([[NCAA]]) (1956–2010)
[[Louisville Rebels]] ([[International Hockey League (1945-2001)|IHL]]) (1957–1960)
[[Kentucky Colonels]] ([[American Basketball Association (1967-1976)|ABA]]) (1970–1976)
[[Louisville Cardinals women's basketball]] (NCAA) (1975–2010)
[[Louisville Panthers]] ([[American Hockey League|AHL]]) (1999–2001)
[[Louisville Fire]] ([[af2]]) (2001–2008)
[[Kentucky Stickhorses]] ([[North American Lacrosse League|NALL]]) (2012–2013)
[[Kentucky Xtreme]] ([[Continental Indoor Football League|CIFL]]) (2013–2014) | seating_capacity = 18,865 (basketball)
19,200 (concerts) }} '''Freedom Hall''' is a multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky]], on the grounds of the [[Kentucky Exposition Center]], which is owned by the [[Commonwealth#US states|Commonwealth]] of [[Kentucky]]. It is best known for its use as a [[basketball]] arena, serving as the home of the [[Louisville Cardinals|University of Louisville Cardinals]] [[Louisville Cardinals men's basketball|men's team]] from 1956 to 2010, the [[Kentucky Colonels]] of the [[American Basketball Association]] from 1970 until the [[ABA-NBA merger]] in June 1976, and the Louisville Cardinals women's team from its inception in 1975 to 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.guide.provations.com/louisville/womensbb2010#pg161 |title=Records: Home/Attendance |work=2010–11 Louisville Cardinals Women's Basketball Media Guide |publisher=University of Louisville Sports information |format=PDF |page=159 |accessdate=March 5, 2011}} The women's team used Freedom Hall as its primary home from its first season, 1975–76, through 1980–81. It then began using a series of smaller arenas, both on campus and off, for nearly two decades, though it used Freedom Hall at least once every season except in 1993–94. The team again made Freedom Hall its primary home starting in 1998–99. Freedom Hall's last regular tenant was the [[Kentucky Stickhorses]] of the [[North American Lacrosse League]], who used it from 2011 until the team folded in 2013. The arena lost its status as Kentuckiana's main indoor sporting and concert venue when the downtown [[KFC Yum! Center]] opened in 2010. It is still used regularly, however, hosting concerts, horse shows, conventions, and basketball games. ==History== Freedom Hall was completed in 1956 in the newly opened [[Kentucky Fair and Exposition Center]] located {{convert|5|mi|km}} south of [[Downtown Louisville]]. It received its name as the result of a statewide essay contest sponsored by the State Fair Board and the [[American Legion]]. Charlotte Owens, a senior at [[DuPont Manual High School]], submitted the winning entry over 6,500 others.{{cite web|url=http://kyexpo.org/history.html|title=Kentucky Exposition Center — Visitors|author=|date=|website=kyexpo.org}} Designed for the nation's premier equestrian competition, the [[Kentucky State Fair World's Championship Horse Show]], the floor length and permanent seating were designed specifically for the almost {{convert|300|ft|m|adj=on}}-long show ring (in comparison, a regulation hockey rink is {{convert|200|ft|m}} long, and a basketball court is only 94 feet). The [[North American International Livestock Exposition]] also is held there each November. [[Muhammad Ali]] fought his first professional fight at Freedom Hall when he won a six-round decision over [[Tunney Hunsaker]].{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} Freedom Hall was also one of the major stops on the Motortown (later MOTOWN) traveling music revue during the early and mid-1960s. [[Judgment Day (2000)]] was also held at the Freedom Hall. ==Tenant history== The [[Kentucky Colonels]] fielded successful teams during their tenure at Freedom Hall, winning the [[American Basketball Association]] (ABA) Championship in the 1974-75 season and reaching the ABA Finals two other times. The 1970-71 team played in the ABA Championship Finals, losing to the [[Utah Stars]] in 7 games. The 1972-73 team advanced to the Finals again, losing to the [[Indiana Pacers]] in 7 games. The Colonels were disbanded when the ABA merged with the [[National Basketball Association]] in 1976. Hall of Fame players [[Dan Issel]] and [[Artis Gilmore]] played for the Colonels during their successful run. Hall of Fame Coach [[Hubie Brown]] coached the Colonels Championship team.{{cite web |url=http://www.remembertheaba.com/Kentucky-Colonels.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-05-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150522142515/http://www.remembertheaba.com/Kentucky-Colonels.html |archivedate=2015-05-22 |df= }} In 1984 the facility was refurbished, including lowering the floor to allow maximum capacity to increase from 16,664 to 18,865 for basketball. It was the full-time home of Cardinal men's basketball from the 1957-58 season to 2010, with the team winning 82% of home games in 50+ seasons. U of L was ranked in the Top 5 in attendance for the past 25 years, with 16 of the last 19 years averaging more than 100% of capacity. In addition to being the home of the Cardinals, Freedom Hall has hosted [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Tournament]] games ten times, including six [[Final Four]]s between 1958 and 1969. The arena has also hosted 11 conference tournaments, nine [[Metro Conference]] Tournaments and two [[Conference USA]] tournaments—2001 and 2003. It has also hosted the [[Sweet Sixteen (KHSAA State Basketball Championship)|Kentucky Boys' High School State Basketball Tournament]] (also known as the Sweet 16) 23 times, including every year from 1965 to 1978. In 1984, the floor of the arena was lowered about {{convert|10|ft|m}} to increase the capacity of the arena from 16,613 to its current figure. In the 1996-97 season Freedom Hall averaged an attendance of 19,590 surpassing arena capacity. Freedom Hall hosts the Championship tractor pull every February during the National Farm Machinery Show. In November 2008 the [[Louisville Fire]] of [[af2]] ceased operations. The Louisville Fire was an Arena Football team who played in Freedom Hall. On the lower level is the Kentucky Athletic Hall of Fame where an engraved bronze plaque honors each inductee.{{cite web|url=http://www.kyathletichalloffame.org/services.htm#Walls+Of+Fame|title=Kentucky Athletic Hall of Fame|first=AllWebCo Design|last=http://allwebcodesign.com/|date=|website=www.kyathletichalloffame.org}} The University of Louisville men's basketball team played their final game at FH in front of a record crowd of 20,138 on March 6, 2010 against Syracuse University, the #1 ranked team in the nation; Louisville won in an upset 78-68. The arena began to gain new tenants in 2012 with the addition of the [[Kentucky Stickhorses]], and in 2013, with the addition of the Kentucky Xtream. However, the Kentucky Stickhorses folded in 2014 after the lack of wins and the lack of attendance. The Kentucky Xtream was suspended in the middle of the season, with other teams playing their remaining games as the team's fate is still in the air. ==Gallery== {| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" style="float:right; margin-left:15px;" | align=center colspan=4| '''UofL Men's Basketball Attendance by Year''' |- ! Year ! Average Attendance ! Games ! {{refimprove|date=May 2009}} '''Golf instruction''' is the art of equipping and training golfers to play better golf through improved awareness of swing cause and effects as a result of the actions by their body, the club, and their effect on the golf ball. Most great golfers have a few common elements that make them great including: proper intentionality, swing repeatability to produce an action that fits the golfers intentionality, and a strong level of automaticity for long lasting enjoyment of the game [[golf]]. Golf instruction is unique as golf consists of five primary skills: shots from a tee (most notable: driving that uses a driver), full shots from the ground (mostly known as "iron shots", pitching (or 3/4 shots designed for distance control, chipping (short shots around the green the require less than a full swing), putting (1 club preferably "the putter") and course strategy or gamesmanship.
Proficiency in teaching golf instruction requires not only technical and physical ability, but also knowledge of the [[rules of golf|rules and etiquette of the game]]. Golf instruction offered on many platforms in the United States including: the PGA of America, GolfTEC, and independent golfers who "may" or "may not" have credentials that are recognized by credible teachers certified sources such as the PGA of America. Although there are many great golf instructors in the United States, who are PGA Class A Professionals, not all great instructors carry this status nor find it a major determiner of golf instruction proficiency.
Golf Instruction can be wide ranging, but many great modern day instructors are able to diagnose and prescribe swing frustrations accurately and present a clear fix that encourages the golfer in the discovery of lasting repeatability from the specific ailment that "plagued" them from a sound repeatable swing to play a golf course successfully (varying terms of success as a golfer ) Many modern instructors include the following in their diagnosis 1. visual feedback through video and bio motion analysis 2. personalized golf club fitting for individual body and swing types 3. on-course play under real conditions 4. mental performance development 5. golf specific body conditioning for optimal golf bio-mechanics
Beginning players can start lesson in several ways, but most do so in either a group or individual setting, covering the five primary skills of golf as noted above [[golf swing]]. Golf is an asymmetrical exercise that can break body balances, requiring also adequate exercises to keep the balance in muscles.<ref>Ahn Hyejung (November 11, 2012), ''World Class Fitness Trainers, [[John Sitaras]]'', [[Golf Digest]] (Korean edition)</ref> Experienced recreational players often return for instruction, either to fix a specific problem they are encountering or to improve their game. Reconstruction of a golf swing to reach a high level of play often involves series of lessons over an extended period of time. Junior golfers often begin receiving instruction by age 10 or younger, and often retain private teachers even when coached on a high school golf team.
Some top instructors who work with professional golfers have become quite well known in their own right over the years, including [[Harvey Penick]], [[Jack Grout]], [[Dick Harmon]], [[David Leadbetter (golf instructor)|David Leadbetter]], [[Butch Harmon]], [[Gary Wiren]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.smithsonianjourneys.org/blog/masters-golf-tournament-interview-with-dr-gary-wiren-180950558/|title=Masters Golf Tournament – Interview with Dr. Gary Wiren|first=Gary Wiren,Patrick|last=Wagner|publisher=Smithsonian Journeys}}</ref> [[Hank Haney]], [[Chip Thomson]], [[Sean Foley (golf instructor)|Sean Foley]], Quentin Patterson and [[Mike Bennett and Andy Plummer]]. Some of the teachers maintain teaching facilities or schools where they or their disciples use their methods or systems. A few instructors focus solely on a particular aspect of the sport, such as [[Dave Pelz]] with the short game. Some famous golfers have been tightly bound with their instructor, such as [[Jack Nicklaus]] with Jack Grout, while in other cases golfers have made high-profile switches from one instructor to another, such as [[Tiger Woods]] moving from Butch Harmon to various other instructors.
Recreational golfers are constantly seeking tips on how to improve, and the major golf publications such as ''[[Golf Magazine]]'' and ''[[Golf Digest]]'' devote substantial portions of their pages to instructional material of various kinds, often written by top-level instructors. Even television broadcasts of professional golf tournaments often contain short instructional segments, delivered by commentators who are also instructors such as [[Peter Kostis]].
Golf instruction may be augmented by training aids such as specially weighting or jointed clubs, putting cups for practice on the den room carpet, mini practice tees with feedback for use in garages, ''et cetera''. Some training aids are sold via television [[infomercials]] and the more peculiar varieties were satirized in the 1996 film ''[[Tin Cup]]''.
Golf instruction is no guarantee of success or improved play in the game. Bad mechanics can be deeply ingrained in a subject's swing, and psychological factors can also hinder progress. The 2009 [[Golf Channel]] program ''The Haney Project: Charles Barkley'' showcased some of these issues, as Hank Haney attempted to fix former [[NBA]] great [[Charles Barkley]]'s infamously bad swing.<ref name="gd-haney">{{cite news | url=http://www.golfdigest.com/instruction/2009/03/charlesbarkley | title=The Haney Project: Can Hank Haney fix this swing? | author=Rudy, Matthew | publisher=''[[Golf Digest]]'' | date=March 2009 | accessdate=2009-04-26}}</ref>
==See also== *[[World Golf Teachers Federation]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Golf}} {{Golf equipment}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Ronnie G. Childress Field at Hennon Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = [[Cullowhee, NC]] | coordinates = {{coord|35.301108|-83.181127|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1978 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Western Carolina University]] | operator = Western Carolina University | surface = Artificial Turf: AstroPlay | construction_cost = Initial $125,000; $1 million in upgrades | architect = | former_names = Childress Field | tenants = [[Western Carolina Catamounts]] | seating_capacity = 1,500 }}
'''Ronnie G. Childress Field at Hennon Stadium'''<ref>{{cite web | title =Facilities | publisher =WCU| year =2008| url =http://www.catamountsports.com/facilities/wcar-facilities.html}}</ref> is the home of the [[Western Carolina Catamounts]] baseball team in [[Cullowhee, North Carolina]].
==Dimensions== The baseball field’s dimensions are {{convert|325|ft|m}} down each line, {{convert|375|ft|m}} to the right and left center power alleys and {{convert|390|ft|m}} to straight away center field. The “Purple Monster” in left field is {{convert|100|ft|m}} long and is divided into two {{convert|50|ft|m|adj=on}} levels. The first and tallest level is {{convert|20|ft|m}} high and the second level is {{convert|14|ft|m}} tall.
325 (LF) | 375 (LC) | 390 (CF) | 375 (RC) | 325 (RF)
The “Purple Monster” Sec. I: 20’ tall & 50’ long – Sec. II: 14’ tall & 50’ long
==History== Hennon Stadium has been home to the Western Carolina University baseball program for 32 years. The baseball facility was officially renamed Childress Field at Hennon Stadium in a dedication ceremony on April 23, 1994.
In 1978, the WCU baseball program moved approximately 200 yards to the east from Haywood Field. Bill Haywood, head baseball coach from 1969 through 1981, and Mr. E.J. Whitmire, a baseball supporter and benefactor from [[Franklin, North Carolina]] were the driving forces behind the building of the facility. The initial cost of the facility in 1978 was $125,000. It was named in honor of the late Ronnie G. Childress, who was a special friend of the baseball program. The James B. Childress family established the Ronnie Childress Memorial Fund Scholarships in 1975 and scholarships have been awarded annually to select WCU baseball players since the fund's inception.
Hennon Stadium has been renovated several times since its construction and has become a showplace of [[Southern Conference]] baseball. Permanent bleacher seating, grandstand chair back seats, and a press box were installed prior to 1990 season. A new scoreboard, concession stands, rest rooms, and a new infield were added prior to the 1991 season.
Childress Field was refurbished in 2003 with nearly $500,000 worth of improvements that included new drainage and irrigation, a [[Bermuda grass]] playing surface, a new warning track, and a new infield playing surface. The baseball field and stadium received yet another renovation<ref>[http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/wcar/sports/m-basebl/auto_pdf/CatsPause_StadiumRenovations.pdf grfx.cstv.com]</ref> in 2011(of approx. $600,000)which included dugout upgrades, the entire stadium painted, new lower-level seating as the stadium was moved 14 feet closer to home plate to accommodate two rows of new chair-back seats. A 36-inch red brick wall was built that stretches between the dugouts in front of the new Yankee Stadium-style slatted seats. A 48-inch brick wall stretchs from each dugout to the outfield fence down the left and right field lines. A batter’s eye has been attached to the centerfield fence and the “purple monster” in left field was repainted.
A new clubhouse on the first-base side and stadium seating design are currently in planning stages.<ref>[http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/wcar/sports/m-basebl/auto_pdf/WCUBASE09_MediaGuide.pdf 2009 Western Carolina Catamounts Baseball Media Guide] pp. 72</ref>
==Southern Conference Tournament== Western Carolina hosted the 1984 and 1986 Southern Conference baseball tournaments at the facility.
==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]]

The winner of the Hokuriku league participates in the post season on the West Japan side of the bracket. ==History== In 1973, the "Kinki" block of the [[Kansai Collegiate American Football League]] was founded with the [[University of Fukui]] and the [[Kanazawa Institute of Technology]] as members. In 1982, Fukui and KIT split from the Kansai League to form the Hokuriku League. {{cite web|title=Kanazawa Evergreen Team History |publisher=Kanazawa The '''International Sport this is a government order''' is a non-governmental and [[Nonprofit organization|nonprofit]] international [[Umbrella company|umbrella association]] of [[Organization|organizations]] working to bring [[Sport|sporting]] activities to all people, including youth and people of all [[Culture|cultures]].
== History == ISCA was founded in 1995 with the purpose that for good health of providing an alternative image of sport in a world of increasingly performance-based attitude of international sports federations. Since its foundation in 1995, ISCA has grown rapidly it has today more than 130 mostly non-governmental affiliated member organizations in 4 continents, from more than 70 countries worldwide and more than 22 million individual members. The association is governed by an [[Committee|executive committee]] of seven elected members and is steered by continental and technical committees. The [[Secretariat (administrative office)|secretariat]] is based in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]].
== Sport and Culture for All == ISCA has a vision of sport that is not just about competition and exercise, but also involves learning, having a good time and making friends. Moreover, it is ISCA's [[philosophy]] that sport regulates [[social behavior]] and creates a feeling of belonging, which in turn leads to a more inclusive [[society]]. ISCA believes that everyone should be given the chance to participate in international activities such as festivals, exchanges and sports [[Tournament|tournaments]] which are understood as unrivaled means of creating international understanding.
== Role == ISCA targets youth, sports, and culture associations from all over the world, primarily non-governmental & voluntary sport organizations which provide a [[Value (marketing)|value-based]] service to their members. The practical reality is to encourage all organizations to assist the members and regions/clubs in fulfilling their aims in providing services and instruments to achieve this. The international interest of the sports organizations’ members today demands that international opportunities are provided indeed, organizations have an interest in developing. [[Organization development|Organizational development]] and inspiration are the basis for fulfilling the goals of the organization in the long run.
To fulfill the above, ISCA concentrates on three key areas: activities, education, and policy-making. In addition to event promotion and educational program administration, the ISCA has an instrumental role in the public debate on sport and culture while striving to influence policies in these areas. Overall, ISCA hopes to improve the general health and well being of individuals in creating a united society.
=== Aims and Objectives === Supporting cross-border understanding through sport and culture.
Promoting sport as a bearer of cultural identity.
Encouraging the broadest possible participation in sports and cultural activities for affiliated members.
<!-- == Members == -->
== CultureSports == ISCA has for the past 7 years published an annual magazine entitled CultureSports. The magazine focuses on a chosen thematic for each edition and gathers information from past experience through ISCA events, debates regarding the treated theme, updates from projects around the globe from its member organizations as well as various sources within thematic sector concerned.
CultureSports 2007 - Health & Integration CultureSports 2006 - The health issue CultureSports 2005 - People's Sport CultureSports 2004 - Sport for unity and development CultureSports 2003 - Education through sport CultureSports 2002 - Across the world CultureSports 2001 - An open mind
CultureSports online [http://isca-web.org/english/library/magazine0/culturesports]
== External links == * [http://www.isca-web.org ISCA]
