[[Jaycee Park (Hot Springs, Arkansas)|Jaycee Park]] (1947-Present) | image = | location = Belding Street and Carson Street
200 W. Belding Street
Hot Springs, AR 71901
{{USA}} | coordinates = {{coord|34|29.7274|N|93|3.0985|W}} | broke_ground = 1908 | opened = [[1908 in baseball|1908]] | renovated = 1909, 1919, 1947, | expanded = 1909, 1947 | closed = 1918 | demolished = 1918, 1947 | owner = Hot Springs Boys and Girls Club | operator = Hot Springs Boys and Girls Club | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Majestic Park; Dean Field | tenants = '''Major League Spring Training'''
[[Detroit Tigers]] (1908)
[[Boston Red Sox]] (1909-1910, 1912-18)
[[Cincinnati Reds]] (1910-1911)
[[Brooklyn Dodgers]] (1910)
[[St. Louis Browns]] (1911)
'''Baseball Schools'''
Ray Doan Baseball School
Rogers Hornsby Baseball College
George Barr Umpire School
'''Minor League'''
[[Hot Springs Bathers]] (CSL) (1947-55)
Chicago White Sox-Minor League Camp (1948-51){{cite web|url=http://arkbaseball.com/tiki-index.php?page=Majestic+Park&structure=Professional+Baseball |title=Arkansas Baseball Encyclopedia | Majestic Park |website=Arkbaseball.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} | seating_capacity = 1,500 | dimensions = }} '''Majestic Park''' (1908–18) was one of the first [[Major League Baseball]] [[spring training]] facilities, located at the corner of Belding Street and Carson Street in [[Hot Springs, Arkansas]]. Majestic Park was the spring training site of the [[Boston Red Sox]] and their star pitcher [[Babe Ruth]] (1909–10, 1912–18), [[Cincinnati Reds]] (1910–11), [[Brooklyn Dodgers]] (1910) and [[St. Louis Browns]] (1911). The location later became the site of Dean Field (1935–47) and Jaycee Park (1947–present). Dean Field served as home to the '''Rogers Hornsby Baseball College'''. The [[Hot Springs Bathers]] minor league team and the [[Chicago White Sox]] (1948–51) minor league Spring Training were held at Jaycee Park. Jaycee Park hosted the 1952 [[Negro League World Series]] and a 1953 exhibition game featuring [[Jackie Robinson]].{{cite web|url=http://arkbaseball.com/tiki-index.php?page=Archives |title=Arkansas Baseball Encyclopedia | Archives |website=Arkbaseball.com |date=1963-05-23 |accessdate=2016-02-24}} The site can claim games featuring both [[List of Major League Baseball career home run leaders|All-time Home Run record]] holders, [[Babe Ruth]] and [[Hank Aaron]] as among those who have played at the site. In 1914, [[Babe Ruth]] was just beginning his career (as a dominant left-handed pitcher) for the Red Sox, while a young Aaron played in the 1952 Negro League World Series.{{cite web|url=http://arkansas.baseballyakker.com/?page_id=221 |title=Baseball In Arkansas Project » Majestic Park |website=Arkbaseball.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=https://arkansasdiamonds.wordpress.com/arkansas-diamonds/miscellaneous-ballparks/majestic-park/ |title=Majestic Park | My Blog |website=Arkansasdiamonds.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} Today, the site has four historical plaques, as part of the '''Hot Springs Historic Baseball Trail.''' Majestic Field, [[Rogers Hornsby]], Jackie Robinson and Hank Aaron each have historical plaques on the site.{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/historic-baseball-trail-documenting-hot-springs-as-birthplace-spring-baseball-will-open-1636073.htm |title=Historic Baseball Trail Documenting Hot Springs as Birthplace of Spring Baseball Will Open on March 29; 45 Percent of Hall of Fame, Other Legendary Players Included |website=Marketwired.com |date=2012-03-26 |accessdate=2016-02-24}} [[File:Jackie Robinson, Brooklyn Dodgers, 1954.jpg|thumb|left|Jackie Robinson, Brooklyn Dodgers, 1954]] Along with Babe Ruth, Jackie Robinson and Hank Aaron, others who performed at the site include [[Ty Cobb]], [[Honus Wagner]], [[Jimmie Foxx]], [[Gil Hodges]], [[Harry Hooper]], [[Cy Young]], [[Rogers Hornsby]], [[Grover Cleveland Alexander]], [[Herb Pennock]], [[Tris Speaker]], and [[Walter Johnson]]. [[The Sporting News]] (1998) ranking of the greatest players ever listed: Babe Ruth (1), Ty Cobb (3), Walter Johnson (4), Hank Aaron (5) and Rogers Hornsby (9).{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/legendary/lisn100.shtml |title=100 Greatest Baseball Players by The Sporting News : A Legendary List by Baseball Almanac |website=Baseball-almanac.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} ==Baseball in Hot Springs== Often called the "birthplace" of Spring Training baseball, Hot Springs first welcomed Major League Baseball in 1886, when the [[Chicago White Stockings]] (now the [[Chicago Cubs]]), brought their coaches and players to the city in preparation for the upcoming season.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotsprings.org/pages/history-buffs/ |title=arlington hotel, oaklawn, gangster museum, hot springs baseball trail, historical landmarks | Hot Springs, Arkansas |website=Hotsprings.org |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=6221 |title=Major League Spring Training in Hot Springs |publisher=Encyclopedia of Arkansas |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} Team President [[Albert Spalding]] (owner of Spalding Sporting Goods) and the team's player/manager [[Cap Anson]], thought the city was an ideal training site for the players. The first baseball location was '''Hot Springs Baseball Grounds'''. Many other Major League teams followed and began training in Hot Springs. Needing venues for teams to use, [[Whittington Park (baseball)|Whittington Park]] was built in 1894, followed by Majestic Park (1908) and [[Fogel Field (Hot Springs)|Fogel Field]] (1912). 134 members of the Baseball Hall of Fame are documented to have trained or played, in Hot Springs. [[File:Red Sox 1916.jpg|thumb|left|World Series Champion Red Sox 1916, Babe Ruth in front row, middle]] ==History of Majestic Field Site== In 1908, the [[Detroit Tigers]] created a practice baseball field at the site. In 1909, Majestic Park was built at the field by Boston Red Sox owner [[John I. Taylor]], who signed a five-year lease on the property as a Spring Training location. Trolleys were routed to turn around in front of the park. The Majestic name came from the '''Majestic Hotel''' in Hot Springs.{{Cite web |url=http://archives.arkansasnews.com/search/level+2+trauma+center+for+arkansas/page/2179/blank/page/1469/void%280%29;/*1235661623495*/page/1854/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-02-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307132856/http://archives.arkansasnews.com/search/level+2+trauma+center+for+arkansas/page/2179/blank/page/1469/void%280%29;/*1235661623495*/page/1854/# |archive-date=2016-03-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Two years later, Taylor would construct [[Fenway Park]] for the Red Sox.{{cite web|last=Murray |first=James |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1993/03/22/128244/when-baseball-sprang-for-hot-springs-nearly-a-century-ago-the-springtime-mecca-for-many-major-league-players-was-a-spa-in-arkansas |title=When Baseball Sprang for Hot Springs |website=Si.com |date=1993-03-22 |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://chapters.sabr.org/boston/projects/research/59-the-land-of-hot-waters |title=The Land of Hot Waters |website=Chapters.sabr.org |date=2012-04-03 |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://fenwaypark100.org/2012/03/27/all-those-springs-ago/ |title=All Those Springs Ago..... |website=Fenwaypark100.org |date=2012-03-27 |accessdate=2016-02-24}} The Boston Red Sox (1909-1910, 1912–18), Cincinnati Reds (1910-1911), Brooklyn Dodgers (1910) and St. Louis Browns (AL) (1911) held Spring Training Camp at the original Majestic Park. The Boston Red Sox were a dominant team, winning four [[World Series]] Championships in their time at Majestic Park (1912, 1915, 1916 and 1918). It was in 1918 spring training that the Red Sox first began to use Babe Ruth in the field, instead of exclusively at pitcher, to take advantage of his hitting.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/BOS/ |title=Boston Red Sox Team History & Encyclopedia |website=Baseball-Reference.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} On March 29, 1918, the [[St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Southern Railway]], owners of the Majestic Park property cancelled the Red Sox lease for 1919 to utilize the ballpark area for railroad needs.{{cite web|url=http://fenwayparkdiaries.com/1918%20red%20sox/1918%20spring%20training.htm |title=1918 BOSTON RED SOX (SPRING TRAINING) |website=Fenwayparkdiaries.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} In 1918, the original Majestic Park facility was demolished, leading to two other fields on the property that had ties to the Major Leagues: Dean Field and Jaycee Park.{{cite web|url=http://arkbaseball.com/tiki-index.php?page=Majestic+Park |title=Arkansas Baseball Encyclopedia | Majestic Park |website=Arkbaseball.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} The relocated field was renamed "Dean Field" in 1938 after Hall of Famer [[Dizzy Dean]] and his brother "Daffy" [[Paul Dean (baseball)|Paul Dean]]. Jaycee Park was built on the adjacent south side of the lot in 1947 to replace [[Ban Johnson Park]], which was located across town.{{cite web|url=http://arkbaseball.com/tiki-index.php?page=Jaycee+Park |title=Arkansas Baseball Encyclopedia | Jaycee Park |website=Arkbaseball.com |date=1963-05-23 |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://arkbaseball.com/tiki-index.php?page=Dean+Field&structure=Professional+Baseball |title=Arkansas Baseball Encyclopedia | Dean Field |website=Arkbaseball.com |date=1963-05-23 |accessdate=2016-02-24}} [[File:Dizzy Dean plaque HOF.jpg|thumb|left|Dizzy Dean plaque HOF. "Dean Field" was named for Dean and his brother Paul "Daffy" Dean]] When Dean Field (1935-1947) and Jaycee Park (1947-Present) evolved, they hosted the '''Rogers Hornsby Baseball College''', the '''George Barr Umpire School''', the [[Chicago White Sox]] (1949–52) Minor League Spring Training and the [[Hot Springs Bathers]] as tenants.{{cite web|url=http://arkbaseball.com/tiki-index.php?page=Dean+Field|title=Arkansas Baseball Encyclopedia - Dean Field|website=Arkbaseball.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://arkansas.baseballyakker.com/?page_id=208|title=Log In ‹ Baseball In Arkansas Project — WordPress|website=Arkansas.baseballyakker.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}} The minor league Bathers (1947-1955) were a [[Cotton States League]] team that was an affiliate of the Chicago White Sox (1947-1951), [[St. Louis Cardinals]] (1954) and the [[Kansas City Athletics]] (1955). [[Paul Dean (baseball)|Paul Dean]] Managed the 1954 team.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/register/team.cgi?city=Hot+Springs&state=AR&country=US|title=Hot Springs, Arkansas Encyclopedia - Baseball-Reference.com|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/register/team.cgi?id=a4497b7c|title=1954 Hot Springs Bathers Statistics - Baseball-Reference.com|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}} ===Baseball Schools=== The '''Roy Doan Baseball School''' operated from 1934–38, attracting hundreds of students and utilized Dean Field and other locations throughout Hot Springs. In 1939, Hall of Fame player and manager Rogers Hornsby, a former instructor with Roy Doan, started his own '''Rogers Hornsby Baseball College.''' Hornsby's six-week event ran until 1952, annually attracting 100-200 prospective professionals and numerous major league scouts. Cy Young, Jimmie Foxx, Tris Speaker and [[Schoolboy Rowe]] were among the instructors. '''The George Barr Umpire School,''' the first ever training school for aspiring umpires, operated in Hot Springs through 1940, being held in conjunction with the baseball schools.{{cite web|url=http://arkbaseball.com/tiki-index.php?page=George+Barr+Umpire+School |title=Arkansas Baseball Encyclopedia | George Barr Umpire School |website=Arkbaseball.com |date=1963-05-23 |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://arkbaseball.com/tiki-index.php?page=Ban+Johnson+Field |title=Arkansas Baseball Encyclopedia | Ban Johnson Field |website=Arkbaseball.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://hsbbt.toursphere.com/en/20-rogers-hornsby-76279.html |title=Hot Springs Baseball Tour |website=Hsbbt.toursphere.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://arkbaseball.com/tiki-index.php?page=Dean+Field |title=Arkansas Baseball Encyclopedia | Dean Field |website=Arkbaseball.com |date=1963-05-23 |accessdate=2016-02-24}} ===Babe Ruth=== Babe Ruth played at Majestic Park for six seasons. In 1914, the lefty pitcher first faced Major League players as a young minor leaguer. Ruth would make the Red Sox' major league roster in 1915 and establish himself as a star pitcher.{{cite web|last=Adomites |first=Paul |url=http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/babe-ruth6.htm |title=Babe Ruth's First Spring Training - Babe Ruth | HowStuffWorks |website=Entertainment.howstuffworks.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} In 1918, during Spring Training, Ruth played first base as an emergency measure in a game against Brooklyn at Whittington Field (now [[Ban Johnson Park]]). The game helped change baseball history. Ruth hit two home runs that day and the second was a reported 573-foot home run that landed in the [[Arkansas Alligator Farm]] across the street.{{cite web |url=https://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/35475 |title=Home Run That Changed Baseball |website=Roadsideamerica.com |accessdate=November 4, 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.mlb.com/cut4/babe-ruth-hit-500-foot-homer-into-alligator-farm/c-268509166 |title=100 years ago, Babe Ruth became Babe Ruth with a 500-foot homer into an Alligator Farm |first=Matt |last=Monagan |website=[[MLB.com]] |date=March 16, 2018 |accessdate=November 4, 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://billjenkinsonbaseball.webs.com/hotspringsbaseball.htm |title=The Official Hot Springs Baseball Historic Trail |first=Bill |last=Jenkinson |date=2011 |accessdate=November 4, 2018}} As a result, the Red Sox began to use Ruth as both a pitcher and a hitter. With Ruth regularly in the 1918 lineup, he led the American League with 11 home runs. He also pitched to a 13–7 record and the Red Sox won the [[1918 World Series|World Series]].{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/players/r/ruthba01.shtml |title=Babe Ruth Statistics and History |website=Baseball-Reference.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} Sold to the New York Yankees in 1920, Ruth went on to total 714 Home Runs, a record that stood until broken by [[Hank Aaron]]. [[File:Babe Ruth Culver Service Photograph, 1916.jpg|thumb|left|Babe Ruth, 1916]] ===Jackie Robinson=== On October 22, 1953, Jackie Robinson played in an exhibition game at Jaycee Park. Having broken Major League Baseball's color barrier in 1947, Robinson and the some other Major League players (including his Dodgers teammate Gil Hodges) toured, calling themselves '''Jackie Robinson's All-Stars.''' Robinson's squad played the Negro American League All-Stars that day, losing 14-9.{{cite web|url=http://arkbaseball.com/tiki-index.php?page=Jackie+Robinson%E2%80%99s+All-Stars+Exhibitions |title=Arkansas Baseball Encyclopedia | Jackie Robinson's All-Stars Exhibitions |website=Arkbaseball.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} Today, there is a plaque at the site as part of the "Hot Springs Baseball Historic Trail" honoring the event.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hotspringsbaseballtrail.com/see-the-trail/jackie-robinson/ |title=Jackie Robinson - Hot Springs Arkansas Historic Baseball Trail |website=Hotspringsbaseballtrail.com |date=1953-10-22 |accessdate=2016-02-24}} ===Hank Aaron: Negro League World Series=== [[File:Hank Aaron 1960.png|thumb|Hank Aaron, Milwaukee Braves, 1960]] In 1952, as referenced in a plaque at the site,{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hotspringsbaseballtrail.com/see-the-trail/hank-aaron/ |title=Hank Aaron - Hot Springs Arkansas Historic Baseball Trail |website=Hotspringsbaseballtrail.com |date=1952-10-01 |accessdate=2016-02-24}} 18-year old shortstop Hank Aaron played for the [[Negro League]] [[Indianapolis Clowns]] against the [[Birmingham Black Barons]] at Jaycee Park in the [[Negro League World Series]]. The World Series was eventually won by the Clowns, with Aaron hitting 5 Home runs and batting over .400. The 1952 World Series was also the last for the Negro Leagues.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hotspringsbaseballtrail.com/see-the-trail/ |title=See The Trail - Hot Springs Arkansas Historic Baseball Trail |website=Hotspringsbaseballtrail.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} Discovered by the Clowns while playing for a semi-pro team (Mobile Black Bears) in a game against them, they signed Aaron in April, 1951. After his performance in the Negro League World Series, Aaron signed with the [[Boston Braves (baseball)|Boston Braves]]. Hank Aaron would eventually become baseball's all-time Home Run leader, with 755 career Home Runs, breaking Babe Ruth's record of 714 on April 8, 1974.{{cite web|url=http://sports.jrank.org/pages/6/Aaron-Hank-Played-in-Negro-League-Major-League.html |title=Hank Aaron - Played In Negro League And Major League - Babe Ruth Accomplishments, Home, and Braves - JRank Articles |website=Sports.jrank.org |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://coe.k-state.edu/annex/nlbemuseum/history/players/aaron.html |title=Negro Leagues Baseball eMuseum: Personal Profiles: Henry "Hank" Aaron |website=Coe.k-state.edu |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}}Heaphy,Leslie A. The Negro Leagues, 1869-1960p.222 ==Media== '''The First Boys of Spring''' is a 2015 documentary on the history of Hot Springs Spring Training. The film features Majestic Park items. Produced by Arkansas filmmaker Larry Foley, it is narrated by Hot Springs area native, actor [[Billy Bob Thornton]].{{cite web|last=Bauman |first=Bonnie |url=http://arkansaslife.com/boys-of-spring/ |title=Boys of Spring |publisher=Arkansas Life |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://thefirstboysofspring.weebly.com |title=Home |website=Thefirstboysofspring.weebly.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://larryfoley.weebly.com/ |title=Larry Foley - Home |website=Larryfoley.weebly.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}} The Foley documentary was aired nationally on the [[MLB Network]] beginning in February, 2016.{{cite web|last=Newman |first=Mark |url=http://m.mlb.com/news/article/164344220/mlb-network-to-air-first-boys-of-spring-doc |title=MLB Network to air 'First Boys of Spring' doc | MLB.com |website=M.mlb.com |date=2016-01-20 |accessdate=2016-02-24}} ==Site Today== In 1953, the Hot Springs Boys and Girls Club built and opened a youth facility on the parcel at 109 West Belding Street, where it still remains today. The '''Jaycee Park Baseball Complex''' and the surrounding fields are utilized for youth baseball and softball. The complex now has eight fields, with Jaycee Park remaining as the largest, with the original 1st base side cement bleachers still intact.{{cite web|url=http://hsbgc.org/ |title=Boys and Girls Club of Hot Springs |publisher=HSBGC |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}}{{cite web|url=https://arkansasdiamonds.wordpress.com/arkansas-diamonds/former-professional-ballparks/jaycee-park/ |title=Jaycee Park | My Blog |website=Arkansasdiamonds.wordpress.com |date=1947-05-01 |accessdate=2016-02-24}} Today, as part of the '''Hot Springs Baseball Historic Trail''', there are four plaques that have been erected at the site: Majestic Field, Hank Aaron, Jackie Robinson and Rogers Hornsby: The Majestic plaque reads: {{Quote box|quote='''Majestic Field''' Built in 1909 as the Boston Red Sox training center, this field was also used by the Cincinnati Reds and Brooklyn Dodgers. In March 1918, during batting practice, Babe Ruth hit many home runs over the distant center field fence, predicting his change from pitcher to slugging outfielder. Cy Young, Tris Speaker, Smoky Joe Wood and many others also trained here.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hotspringsbaseballtrail.com/see-the-trail/majestic-field/ |title=Majestic Field - Hot Springs Arkansas Historic Baseball Trail |website=Hotspringsbaseballtrail.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-24}}|width=30em|align=center}} Hank Aaron's plaque reads: {{Quote box|quote=At this field on October 1, 1952, 18-year old Hank Aaron and the Indianapolis Clowns played in one of 12 games of the Negro League World Series against the Birmingham Black Barons. During this series, Aaron he batted .402 and slugged five home runs leading his team to the championship. "Hammerin' Hank" eventually broke Babe Ruth's home run record by recording 755 Major League home runs.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotspringsbaseballtrail.com/see-the-trail/hank-aaron/|title=Hank Aaron « Hot Springs Arkansas Historic Baseball Trail|website=Hotspringsbaseballtrail.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}|width=30em|align=center}} The plaque for Jackie Robinson says the following: {{Quote box|quote=One of the most important events in Hot Springs history occurred where you are standing. On October 22, 1953, the legendary Jackie Robinson, played an exhibition game here at Jaycee field with Gil Hodges, Luke Easter and other fellow Big Leaguers. He is recognized as the man who broke the color barrier in Major League baseball.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotspringsbaseballtrail.com/see-the-trail/jackie-robinson/|title=Jackie Robinson « Hot Springs Arkansas Historic Baseball Trail|website=Hotspringsbaseballtrail.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}|width=30em|align=center}} The Rogers Hornsby plaque at the site reads: {{Quote box|quote=At the conclusion of his historic Hall of Fame career, Rogers "The Rajah" Hornsby returned to Hot Springs to oversee the nationally-recognized baseball school. Founded here in 1933 by Ray Doan, the school prospered for years, training young players from around the country. Instructors included George Sisler, Grover Cleveland Alexander and Dizzy Dean.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotspringsbaseballtrail.com/see-the-trail/rogers-hornsby/|title=Rogers Hornsby « Hot Springs Arkansas Historic Baseball Trail|website=Hotspringsbaseballtrail.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}|width=30em|align=center}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.digitalballparks.com/SpringTraining/BanJohnson.html Hot Springs Spring Training Photos] *[http://www.hotspringsbaseballtrail.com/ Hot Springs Historic Baseball Trail] {{Boston Red Sox}} {{Cincinnati Reds}} {{Los Angeles Dodgers}} {{Baltimore Orioles}} [[Category:Negro league baseball]] [[Category:History of baseball]] [[Category:Baseball field]] [[Category:Boston Red Sox spring training venues]] [[Category:Brooklyn Dodgers spring training venues]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Detroit Tigers spring training venues]] [[Category:Cincinnati Reds spring training venues]] [[Category:St. Louis Browns spring training venues]] [[Category:Babe Ruth]] [[Category:Jackie Robinson]] [[Category:Negro World Series]] [[Category:Spring training ballparks]] [[Category:1908 establishments in Arkansas]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1908]] [[Category:1947 disestablishments in Arkansas]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = T. Howard McCasland Field House | nickname = The Field House | image = [[Image:OU FieldHouse.jpg|250px]] | location = 151 West Brooks Street
Norman, OK 73019 | opened = January 13, 1928 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of Oklahoma]] | operator = [[University of Oklahoma]] | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = [[Oklahoma Sooners]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]])
Men's basketball (1928 - 1975)
Women's volleyball
Men's wrestling
Men's gymnastics | seating_capacity = 5,000 }} The '''McCasland Field House''' is a multi-purpose [[List of indoor arenas|indoor arena]] on the [[University of Oklahoma]] main campus in [[Norman, Oklahoma]]. Home of the [[college basketball|basketball]] [[Oklahoma Sooners|Sooners]] until 1975, the Field House currently hosts the men's [[wrestling]], women's [[volleyball]], and men's [[gymnastics]] teams. The Field House is named for T. Howard McCasland, a two-sport star who was the captain of the 1916 [[basketball]] team and an end for the [[American football|football]] team. The facility opened with a basketball game between the Sooners and the [[University of Kansas]] [[Kansas Jayhawks|Jayhawks]] on January 13, 1928, which the Sooners won 45-19. When it opened, the facility held over 5,000 people. It is rather unknown, these days on campus, that the Fieldhouse once witnessed concerts by [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[Frank Sinatra]] and [[Elvis Presley]] in the 1960s and 1970s. As the campus was constructed around the Field House, parking for fans disappearedUpchurch, Jay. [http://www.oufoundation.org/sm/winter2003/story.asp?ID=40 The House That Basketball Built] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040107125901/http://www.oufoundation.org/sm/winter2003/story.asp?ID=40 |date=2004-01-07 }}. ''Sooner Magazine'', Winter 2003. and attendance at games dwindled as well. After the [[Lloyd Noble Center]] opened in 1975 and the basketball teams moved south to the new facility, the Field House seemed forgotten and neglected. Plans for refurbishment began in the 1990s along with other campus improvements,Burr, Carol. [http://www.oufoundation.org/sm/summer2002/thams.asp?ID=57 Under Construction] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051030000000/http://www.oufoundation.org/sm/summer2002/thams.asp?ID=57 |date=October 30, 2005 }}. ''Sooner Magazine'', Summer 2002. and fundraising began in earnest in September 1997.Burr, Carol. [http://www.oufoundation.org/PN/winter2004/ Dreams of Great Expectations Realized]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ''Priority Magazine'', Winter 2004. In 2005 the initial phase of a $6 million renovation project was completed, including the building's first-ever climate control system, refurbishment of the historic wood floor, new chair-back and retractable seats. The facility had to be completely rewired, not only to handle the new heating and air-conditioning systems (its first ever) and the new lighting and state-of-the-art sound and video systems, but to bring the building up to current [[National Electrical Code (US)|electrical code standards]]. The next phase of renovations to the Field House, scheduled to be completed by 2012, include locker room upgrades, additions of restrooms and concessions, and expansion of the wrestling practice facility from its current {{convert|4500|sqft|m2}} to more than {{convert|8000|sqft|m2}}. Finally, all of the building's windows, a distinguishing feature of the Field House, will be replaced, along with the roof.Upchurch, Jay. ''New Digs''. ''Sooner Magazine'', Winter 2007, p. 15-17. ==See also== *[[2020 Summer Olympics|Tulsa Olympics]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.soonersports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?&DB_OEM_ID=31000&ATCLID=208803875 Official Howard McCasland Field House information page] {{University of Oklahoma|athletics}} {{Oklahoma Sooners men's basketball navbox}} {{Oklahoma Sooners women's basketball navbox}} {{coord|35.208034|-97.442535|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:College wrestling venues in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct college basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Oklahoma Sooners basketball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Oklahoma]] [[Category:University of Oklahoma campus]] [[Category:1928 establishments in Oklahoma]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1928]] [[Category:College gymnastics venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]]

{{infobox country at games | NOC = MAR | NOCname = [[Moroccan Olympic Committee]]
{{lang-ar|اللجنة الأولمبية الوطنية المغربية|links=no}} | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1976 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.marocolympique.org }} {{fr icon}} | location = [[Montreal]] | competitors = | sports = | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} During the '''[[1976 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada, '''[[Morocco]]''', along with many other countries, boycotted due to the participation of [[New Zealand at the 1976 Summer Olympics|New Zealand]], which still had sporting links with [[South Africa]]. Athletes from [[Cameroon]], [[Egypt]], Morocco, and [[Tunisia]] competed on July 18–20 before these nations withdrew from the Games. ==Results by event== ===[[Athletics at the 1976 Summer Olympics|Athletics]]=== '''Men's 5.000 metres''' * [[Mohamed Benbaraka]] :* Heat — did not start (→ did not advance, no ranking) ===[[Boxing at the 1976 Summer Olympics|Boxing]]=== '''Men's Light Flyweight (– 48 kg)''' * [[Abderahim Najim]] *# First Round — Lost to [[Park Chan-Hee]] (KOR), DSQ-3 ==References== *[http://www.la84foundation.org/5va/reports_frmst.htm Official Olympic Reports] {{Nations at the 1976 Summer Olympics}} [[Category:Nations at the 1976 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Morocco at the Summer Olympics by year|1976 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:1976 in Moroccan sport]] {{Morocco-sport-stub}} {{1976-Olympic-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | name = Phoenix Rising FC Soccer Complex | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = File:PRFC Soccer Complex.jpg | caption = A nearly complete PRFC Soccer Complex | fullname = | former_names = | address = {{nowrap|751 North McClintock Drive}}
[[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]], [[Arizona|AZ]] 85281 | coordinates = {{coord|33|26|15|N|111|54|20|W|display=it}} | broke_ground = February 1, 2017 | built = | opened = March 25, 2017 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Phoenix Rising FC]] | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = [[DLR Group]] | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = [http://www.rummelconstruction.com Rummel Construction] | main_contractors = | capacity = 6,200 | suites = 15 | record_attendance = 7,707
(October 26, 2018 vs.
[[Swope Park Rangers]]) | dimensions = {{convert|116|x|74|yd|m|abbr=on}} | acreage = 15.8 | tenants = [[Phoenix Rising FC]] ([[USL Championship|USLC]]) (2017–present) }} '''Phoenix Rising FC Soccer Complex''' is a 15.8-acre soccer-specific training and stadium facility located in the [[Salt River Pima–Maricopa Indian Community]] near [[Tempe, Arizona]].{{cite news|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/scottsdale/2016/11/28/arizona-united-sc-reveals-new-name-and-logo-plus-stadium-plans-2017-season/94569050/|title=Arizona United SC reveals new name and logo, plus stadium plans for 2017 season|work=Alejandro Barahona|publisher=Arizona Republic|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=March 21, 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.socceramerica.com/article/71396/usl-phoenix-rising-fc-unveils-stadium-plans.html|title=USL: Phoenix Rising FC unveils stadium plans|work=Paul Kennedy|publisher=Soccer America|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=March 21, 2017}} It is the home of [[Phoenix Rising FC]] of the [[USL Championship]]. The complex has a 6,200-seat temporary stadium with luxury suites, separate training field, and parking area and is privately funded.{{cite web|url=http://www.12news.com/sports/phoenixs-pro-soccer-team-unveils-new-stadium-name/357069461|title=Phoenix's pro soccer team unveils new stadium, name|publisher=12news.com|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=March 21, 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://ktar.com/story/1371927/phoenix-area-pro-soccer-team-announces-new-name-stadium/|title=Phoenix-area pro soccer team announces new name, stadium complex|publisher=KTAR News|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=March 21, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.phxrisingfc.com/news_article/show/727068?referrer_id=2995073|title=Arizona United SC Unveils New Name and Exciting Improvements in Anticipation of 2017 Season|publisher=Phoenix Rising FC|date=November 27, 2016|accessdate=March 21, 2017}} ==History== Phoenix Rising FC is a candidate for [[Major League Soccer]] expansion. If the franchise is awarded, a permanent stadium will be constructed on the site.{{cite web|url=http://www.12news.com/sports/phoenix-rising-fc-officially-files-for-major-league-soccer-expansion/395119013|title=Phoenix Rising FC officially files for Major League Soccer expansion|publisher=12news.com|date=January 31, 2017|accessdate=March 21, 2017}} The first game at the complex was held on March 25, 2017, when Rising FC hosted [[Toronto FC II]] in front of a crowd of 6,890 fans.{{cite web|url=http://www.uslsoccer.com/news_article/show/774152?referrer_id=2333971|title=Rising FC Players Thrilled by Stadium, Fans|work=Nicholas Murray|publisher=United Soccer League (USL)|date=March 26, 2017|accessdate=March 26, 2017}} They won their first game at the stadium on April 8 by defeating [[LA Galaxy II]] 2–1. [[Luke Rooney (footballer)|Luke Rooney]] scored both goals, the first one on a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty kick]]. They were the first goals scored by the team in their new stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.uslsoccer.com/news_article/show/779193?referrer_id=2333971|title=Rooney Rises to Occasion for Phoenix|work=Nicholas Murray|publisher=United Soccer League|date=April 8, 2017|accessdate=April 9, 2017}} [[File:Phoenix Rising Sports Complex 2017.03.25.jpg|thumb|center|700px|The inaugural match for the Phoenix Rising Sports Complex on March 25, 2017, [[Toronto FC II]] vs. [[Phoenix Rising FC]]]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Phoenix Rising FC}} {{USL Championship venues}} {{Arizona-stadium-stub}} [[Category:Phoenix Rising FC]] [[Category:USL Championship stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2017]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tempe, Arizona]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Arizona]] [[Category:Sports venues in Tempe, Arizona]] [[Category:2017 establishments in Arizona]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Presley Askew Field | nickname = | image = | fullname = | former_names = | location = S Locust St and Wells St
[[Las Cruces, New Mexico|Las Cruces]], [[New Mexico|NM]] | coordinates = {{coord|32.27833|-106.744484|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = November 14, 1981{{cite web|title=2015 NM State Baseball Media Guide|url=http://viewer.zmags.com/publication/b18adbb8?ATCLID=209573267&SPSID=9966&SPID=602&DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=1900#/b18adbb8/16|publisher=New Mexico State University|accessdate=February 28, 2015|pages=14-15}} | renovated = 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2003, 2007, 2014 | expanded = 2014 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[New Mexico State University]] | operator = New Mexico State University | surface = | scoreboard = Electronic with video display | estimated_cost = 2014 Renovation, $1.4 Million | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 1,000 | record_attendance = 1,615
(February 27, 2015
vs
[[Incarnate Word Cardinals]]){{cite web|title=NM State Baseball Fans Break Attendance Record; Aggies Fall 6-4 in Home Opener|url=http://www.nmstatesports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=1900&ATCLID=209913549|publisher=New Mexico State University|accessdate=February 28, 2015|date=February 27, 2015|quote=The New Mexico State baseball fell 6-4 in the season opener to Incarnate Word in front of a record-breaking crowd (1,615) at the newly renovated Presley Askew Field, Friday, Feb. 27.}} | dimensions = Left: 345 ft
Alleys: 385 ft
Center: 400 ft
Right: 345 ft | tenants = [[New Mexico State University]] [[New Mexico State Aggies|Aggies]] [[College baseball|baseball]] }} '''Presley Askew Field''' is a [[baseball]] [[Baseball field|venue]] located on the campus of [[New Mexico State University]] in [[Las Cruces, New Mexico|Las Cruces]]. It is home to the [[New Mexico State Aggies]] [[College baseball|baseball]] team, a member of the [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[Western Athletic Conference]]. The field is named after former Aggies baseball coach [[Presley Askew]] and has a capacity of 1,000 fans. Features of the field include a [[press box]], [[public address]], bullpens, and batting cages.[http://www.lascrucescvb.org/html/las_cruces_baseball_facilities.html Las Cruces Baseball Facilities] at lascrucescvb.com, URL accessed December 21, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5mCUUxrlQ Archived] 12/21/09 Going into the 2015 season, the [[New Mexico State Aggies baseball|New Mexico State Aggies]] have a 619-366-1 record in 31 years of play for a {{winpct|619|366|1}} winning percentage. ==Renovations== Numerous improvements have been made over the life of the stadium. In 1996, new grandstands, clubhouse, dugouts were added. Lights were added the next year and the stadium's first night game was held on February 21, 1997. A new fence was added prior to the 1998 season. Improvements continued in 1999 with a new press box, new restrooms, a sound system, and a new scoreboard. In 2003, the dugouts were renovated and improvements to the playing field were made. Improvements in 2005 enhanced spectator viewing with backstop changes from chain to mesh. The scoreboard was replaced in 2007. A major improvement starting in May, 2014 was made with the addition of chairback seating and an expansion of the south stands. Additional 2014 improvements included dugout renovation and expansion, upgrades to clubhouse lighting, sprinkler system repair, fencing upgrades, pressbox upgrades, and upgrades to the scoreboard. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{Western Athletic Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{New Mexico NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in New Mexico]] [[Category:New Mexico State Aggies baseball]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Las Cruces, New Mexico]] [[Category:1981 establishments in New Mexico]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1981]] {{NewMexico-baseball-venue-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox Musical | name = Shane Warne: The Musical | subtitle = | image =Shane Warne The Musical.jpg | caption = | music = [[Eddie Perfect]] | lyrics = Eddie Perfect | book = Eddie Perfect | basis = [[Shane Warne]] | premiere_date = 10 December 2008 | premiere_location = [[Melbourne Athenaeum|Athenaeum Theatre]], [[Melbourne]] | productions = 2008 Australian tour
2013 Adelaide/Melbourne | awards = 2009 Helpmann Award Best New Australian Work 2008 Green Room Award Best New Australian Musical }} '''Shane Warne: The Musical''' is a musical comedy by [[Eddie Perfect]] based on the life of Australian [[cricket]]er [[Shane Warne]]. [[The Daily Telegraph]] described the musical as "a warts-and-all account of the spin bowler's controversy-laden career and roller-coaster personal life set to soul, rock, opera, gospel music – and even a bit of Bollywood."{{cite news|last=Malkin|first=Bonnie|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/3699759/Shane-Warne-backs-Musical-based-on-his-life.html|title=Shane Warne backs musical based on his life|date=10 December 2008|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=6 February 2009}} ==Plot== The musical consists of two acts: the first act covering Warne's aborted [[Australian rules football]] career, his marriage and his rise to success as a Test cricketer while the controversial issues that Warne was involved in; such as his drug offence, infidelity and the [[John the bookmaker controversy]] feature in the second act. The musical finishes with a chorus "Everyone's a little bit like Shane".{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/australasia/warnes-life-flashes-before-his-eyes--to-music-1060773.html|title=Warne's life flashes before his eyes – to music|last=Boztas|first=Senay|date=10 December 2008|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=6 February 2009}} The musical contains a series of songs about various incidents in Warne's life both on and off the cricket field, including: *"The Tale Of Warne"; *"Run"; *"Get Offa The Couch"; *"How do you spell success? [[Australian Institute of Sport|AIS]]"; *"We're Going There"; *"Piss It All Away"; *"Hollywood"; *"[[Ball of the Century|The Ball]]"; *"Payin' Attention Now"; *"Dancing with the Stars"; *"We Never Cross The Line"; *"The Away Game"; *"Is The Sun The Moon?"; *"I'm Coming Home"; *"Shine Like Shane"; *"What About That, Shane?"; *"The Ashes"; *"Bunny in the headlights" (about [[Daryll Cullinan]]); and *"What an SMS I’m in".{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/the_tls/article5544840.ece|title=Singing with Shane Warne|last=Gruber|first=Fiona|date=19 January 2009|work=[[The Times Literary Supplement]]|accessdate=6 February 2009}} ==Development== After five years of solo cabaret shows, Perfect had wanted to write a full-scale musical. Seeking a subject, Perfect reflected that: "with every headline I read about Warnie, came the realisation that here was a simple yet complicated, positive yet flawed, honest but naive, charming, philandering, freakishly talented and endlessly divisive man. And that, I thought, is a great character."http://www.au.timeout.com/sydney/comedy/features/4015/shane-warne-the-musical-interview The [[Adelaide Cabaret Festival]] presented a work-in-progress showing on 17 June 2007 at the Dunstan Playhouse, [[Adelaide Festival Centre]].https://www.ausstage.edu.au/pages/event/71254 The 2008 [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]] included a further showing at the [[Hi Fi Bar and Ballroom]].https://www.ausstage.edu.au/pages/event/85842 ==Productions== The full Australian production, directed by [[Neil Armfield]] with choreography by [[Gideon Obarzanek]] and with Perfect in the title role, opened at the [[Melbourne Athenaeum|Athenaeum Theatre]] in [[Melbourne]] on 10 December 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/entertainment/arts/as-musical-fodder-king-of-spin-faces-the-first-test/2008/10/18/1223750404904.html|title=As musical fodder, king of spin faces the first test|last=Bailey|first=John|date=19 October 2008|work=[[The Age]]|accessdate=6 February 2009}} It toured to the [[Regal Theatre]] in Perth from 18 March 2009 and the [[Enmore Theatre]] in Sydney from 15 May 2009. A 2013 revision included a new beginning and ending, new scenes and a revised structure, four new songs and new characters including Liz Hurley. It played short seasons in June for the Adelaide Cabaret Festival at [[Her Majesty's Theatre, Adelaide|Her Majesty’s Theatre]], then at [[Hamer Hall, Melbourne|Hamer Hall]] in Melbourne. This production, directed by Simon Phillips, had a cast that included Perfect, [[Lisa McCune]], [[Shane Jacobson]] and [[Christie Whelan|Christie Whelan-Browne]].{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/musicals/warne-out-not-even-a-halfchance-20130613-2o6g0.html|title=Warne out? Not even a half-chance|last=Mathieson|first=Craig|date=14 June 2013|work=[[The Age]]|accessdate=24 February 2016}} A cast album was recorded during the season at Hamer Hall and released in 2014.http://castalbums.org/recordings/Shane-Warne-The-Musical-2013-Concert-Cast/28211 ==Reception== While initially suspicious of the project,{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/features/shane-warne-the-musical-1048567.html|title=Shane Warne: The Musical|last=Marks|first=Kathy|date=3 December 2008|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=6 February 2009}} Warne later gave his approval after watching the show, saying "I think Eddie and his team have written the musical in a respectful and sympathetic way, and that they have captured my fun, larrikin side." The musical has been able to draw an audience that would not normally attend musicals with Perfect saying "You see young blokes making their way to their seats carrying armfuls of beers for their mates, just like they do at the cricket. It's like Reformation theatre when people were buying oranges to throw at the actors – why shouldn’t they have fun."{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.co.za/article.aspx?id=289963|title=Warne musical draws the blokes|date=2 February 2009|work=[[Daily Dispatch]]|accessdate=6 February 2009}} Reviews for the musical have been mainly positive. *''[[Herald Sun]]'': "[The musical] is a wild, funny, outrageous, and by the end, surprisingly moving account of the champion spin bowler's life so far. [...] Among the fun, there's genuine respect for [Warne's] enormous talent but it doesn't gloss over his personal failings."{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,24753094-2902,00.html |title=Wicked wicket ways of Shane Warne: The Musical |last=Vickery |first=Colin |date=5 December 2008 |work=[[Herald Sun]] |accessdate=6 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207162927/http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,24753094-2902,00.html |archivedate=7 December 2008 }} *''[[The Independent]]'' "The mid-field marriage of a likeable star, fake bowling, plenty of sporting puns, and a moderate raunch factor had the crowds chuckling and clapping along. [...] [The musical makes] his life an appealingly debauched song and dance, playing with musical styles from nicely-harmonized gospel to gangsta rap." *''Australian Stage'': "The story is thin, the songs are wordy and the sound wasn’t great, so many of the lyrics were lost. [...] Without wanting to cut down a tall poppy, there are certainly holes in the script and score. But who cares!? The performances by the ensemble cast are brilliant, the packed audience loved it, the upfront ''this-is-what-I-am-and-who-gives-a-shit-what-you-think-about-me'' attitude (reflecting Shane's own character) is refreshing, the show will bring in thousands of audience-goers who love sport and Shane, but rarely go to the theatre (which is fantastic), so what more can a new Australian musical do?"{{cite web|url=http://www.australianstage.com.au/reviews/melbourne/shane-warne-the-musical-2131.html|title=Shane Warne: The Musical|last=Kooperman|first=Paul|date=13 December 2008|work=Australian Stage Online|accessdate=6 February 2009}} *[[Gideon Haigh]], ''[[The Guardian]]'': "Perfect's vision is an almost unimprovable mingling of satire and homage, cheek and deference, music and comedy."{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2008/dec/12/shane-warne-the-musical|title=Warne takes centre stage again as spinner proves Perfect vehicle for satire|last=Haigh|first=Gideon|date=12 December 2008|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=6 February 2009}} ==Awards and Nominations== *2008 [[Green Room Awards]] **Best New Australian Musical ('''winner''') **[[Green Room Award for Male Actor in a Leading Role (Music Theatre)|Male Artist in a Leading Role]] – Eddie Perfect (nominated) **[[Green Room Award for Female Actor in a Featured Role (Music Theatre)|Female Artist in a Featured Role]] – Rosemarie Harris (nominated) **Featured Ensemble Performance – The Ensemble (nominated) *2009 [[Helpmann Awards]]{{cite web |url=http://www.helpmannawards.com.au/default.aspx?s=nominees&year=2009&cid=7 |title=Nominees |publisher=Helpmannawards.com.au |date= |accessdate=20 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612074232/http://www.helpmannawards.com.au/default.aspx?s=nominees&year=2009&cid=7 |archivedate=12 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} **[[Helpmann Award for Best New Australian Work|Best New Australian Work]] – Eddie Perfect ('''winner''') **[[Helpmann Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]] (nominated) **[[Helpmann Award for Best Choreography in a Musical|Best Choreography in a Musical]] – Gideon Obarzanek (nominated) **[[Helpmann Award for Best Male Actor in a Musical|Best Male Actor in a Musical]] – Eddie Perfect (nominated) *2009 [[Victorian Premier's Literary Award]][http://www.literaryawards.com.au/victorianpremiers.html#music Literaryawards.com.au: 2009 2009 Victorian Premier's Literary Awards Shortlists: The Prize for Best Music Theatre Script] **[[Victorian Premier's Literary Awards Prize for Best Music Theatre Script|Prize for Musical Theatre Script]] ('''winner''') ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== sportspeople|Warne]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of men|Warne]]

revision.text:
A '''skwal''' is the main piece of equipment used for skwalling, a hybrid sport combining the carving of [[skiing]] and riding feel of [[snowboarding]]. It is similar to a [[snowboard]] or [[monoski]] in that both feet are attached to the same board. On a skwal the feet are one in front of the other, in line with the direction the skwal is pointing in. This differs from snowboards (in which the feet are side-on to the direction of the board) and monoskis (in which the feet point in the direction of the board, but are side-by-side).
[[File:Skwal.jpg|thumb|skwalling]] == History == The skwal was invented by two [[France|French]] ski-school instructors [[:fr:Thias_Balmain|Patrick "Thias" Balmain]] and Manuel Jammes, with the first prototype appearing in 1992. They envisaged it as a way to offer different sensations to what skiing and [[snowboarding]] could offer, at a time when 'carving' skis were only just starting to take off. A French company called Lacroix took an interest, recruited [[:fr:Thias_Balmain|Patrick Balmain]], and started producing skwals. A few years later, [[:fr:Thias_Balmain|Patrick]] left Lacroix and started his own skwal-making company. There are now several other makers of skwals, though the sport has never gained the widespread popularity its creators predicted - possibly due to the perceived difficulty of the sport. The sport is nonetheless gathering a few more adepts every year.
== See also ==
*[[Sport]] **[[Grass skiing]] **[[Water skiing]] **[[Winter sport]] ***[[Snowshoe]] ***[[Skiing]] *[[Alpine skiing]] *[[Freestyle skiing]] *[[Mogul skiing]] *[[Monoski]] *[[Skiboarding]] *[[Snowkiting]] *[[Teleboard]]
==External links== *[http://figmentoriginal.com/aceskwal.htm Ace Skwal] *[http://www.skwalzone.org Skwalzone] *[http://www.skwalattack.ch Skwalattack] *[http://www.monoski-skwal.com Monoski-Skwal]

{{Infobox MMA event | name = Strikeforce: Melendez vs. Healy | image = Melendez vs. healy.JPG | promotion = [[Strikeforce (mixed martial arts)|Strikeforce]] | date = Cancelled | venue = [[Power Balance Pavilion]] | city = [[Sacramento, California]], United States | gate = | attendance = | previousevent= [[Strikeforce: Rousey vs. Kaufman]] |followingevent= [[Strikeforce: Cormier vs. Mir]] }} '''''Strikeforce: Melendez vs. Healy''''' was a planned [[mixed martial arts]] event that was to be held by [[Strikeforce (mixed martial arts)|Strikeforce]]. The event would have taken place on September 29, 2012 at the [[Power Balance Pavilion]] in [[Sacramento, California]].<ref name="strikeforce63">{{cite web|url=http://www.strikeforce.com/event/SF4 |title=Strikeforce: Melendez vs. Healy |publisher=strikeforce.com|date=August 30, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mmajunkie.com/news/29874/gilbert-melendez-vs-pat-healy-headlines-strikeforces-september-event.mma |title=Gilbert Melendez vs. Pat Healy headlines Strikeforce's September event |publisher=mmajunkie.com |accessdate=2012-07-25}}</ref>
==Cancellation== On September 23, 2012, Strikeforce announced it was cancelling this event, as [[Showtime (TV channel)|Showtime]] opted to not air it following lightweight champion Gilbert Melendez suffering a knee injury in training, taking him out of a planned title defense against Pat Healy. Strikeforce CEO Scott Coker stated, "Without a television partner, we simply could not move forward with this event. We wish Gilbert a speedy recovery and will work diligently and quickly to reschedule the fighters affected by this news on upcoming cards."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.strikeforce.com/news/SF4-cancel-news |title=Strikeforce Announces Cancellation of Saturday's Event in Sacramento |publisher=strikeforce.com|date=September 23, 2012}}</ref>
The Melendez/Healy and Payan/Bravo bouts were both rescheduled for [[Strikeforce: Marquardt vs. Saffiedine]] on January 12, 2013, where Estevan Payan defeated Michael Bravo by second round TKO. However, Gilbert Melendez was replaced by [[Jorge Masvidal]], and later, Kurt Holobaugh in the planned bout with Pat Healy due to injuries.
The proposed bout between Nah-Shon Burrell & Yuri Villefort was rescheduled for [[UFC 157]] on February 23, 2013 following both fighters' signings with the UFC after the closure of Strikeforce in January 2013. Burrell defeated Villefort via unanimous decision.
== Cancelled fight card ==
=== Preliminary card (Showtime Extreme) === *'''Lightweight bout: [[Estevan Payan]] vs. Michael Bravo'''<ref name="strikeforce63" /> *'''Light Heavyweight bout: [[Mike Kyle]] vs. Dion Staring'''<ref name="strikeforce63" /> *'''Welterweight bout: [[Nah-Shon Burrell]] vs. [[Yuri Villefort]]'''<ref name="strikeforce63" /> *'''Women's Bantamweight bout: [[Amanda Nunes]] vs. [[Cat Zingano]]'''<ref name="strikeforce63" /> *'''Lightweight bout: [[Jorge Gurgel]] vs. [[Mizuto Hirota]]'''<ref name="strikeforce63" />
=== Main card (Showtime) === *'''Lightweight bout: [[Josh Thomson]] vs. [[Caros Fodor]]'''<ref name="strikeforce63" /> *'''Light Heavyweight bout: [[Gian Villante]] vs. [[Guto Inocente]]'''<ref name="strikeforce63" /> *'''Lightweight bout: [[Isaac Vallie-Flagg]] vs. [[Adriano Martins (fighter)|Adriano Martins]]'''<ref name="strikeforce63" /> *'''Welterweight bout: [[Jorge Santiago]] vs. [[Quinn Mulhern]]'''<ref name="strikeforce63" /> *'''[[List of Strikeforce champions#Lightweight Championship|Lightweight Championship]] bout: [[Gilbert Melendez]] (c) vs. [[Pat Healy (fighter)|Pat Healy]]'''<ref name="strikeforce63" />

V.''' or '''TV Bittenfeld''' is a [[handball]] club from [[Waiblingen]], town of [[Bittenfeld]], [[Germany]]. This club has been played in 2nd division of German Handball League, [[Handball-Bundesliga]] since season 2006/07 until 2014/15. After successful 3rd place in overall ranking of season 2014/15, the team rose to the 1st division of German League and changed name to '''TVB 1898 Stuttgart'''.http://wg.tvb1898.de/index.php?id=162&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=2750&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=163&cHash=b8eca2742f The team's home games take place in [[Scharrena Stuttgart]]. Due to restricted capacity of home arena, some of the games are held in [[Porsche-Arena]] in the nearby area. ==History== The team has played five seasons in the 2nd South Ligue between 2006-2011. At the end of the season 2010/2011 TV Bittenfeld finished as fourth. This allowed the team to play in the newly founded 2nd Handball National League (German: Bundesliga). Coach of the team was Jürgen Schweikardt, who was supported by his assistant coach Heiko Burmeister. The biggest success so far the club got in the season 2014/15, when TV Bittenfeld took the 3rd ranking position in the final standings, which entitled the transfer to the first (or main) German League. To performe in season 2015/16 team TV Bittenfeld has modified the name to TVB 1898 Stuttgart.http://wg.tvb1898.de/index.php?id=162&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=2750&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=163&cHash=b8eca2742f The second team of TV Bittenfeld played until the season 2010/2011 in so-called Land League. The team won the first place there and now plays in the [[Baden-Württemberg|Württemberg]] League. The team is trained by Michael Rill and Peter Seiz. ==Team== ===Season 2015/2016=== {| class="wikitable" ! Nr. !! Name !! Nationality !! Position !! {{Infobox film | name = The Slugger's Wife | image = The Slugger's Wife VideoCover.jpeg | caption = | director = [[Hal Ashby]] | producer = [[Ray Stark]] | writer = [[Neil Simon]] | starring = [[Michael O'Keefe]]
[[Rebecca De Mornay]]
[[Martin Ritt]]
[[Randy Quaid]]
[[Cleavant Derricks (actor)|Cleavant Derricks]] | music = [[Patrick Williams (composer)|Patrick Williams]] | cinematography = [[Caleb Deschanel]] | editing = Don Brochu
George C. Villaseñor | distributor = [[Columbia Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1985|03|29}} | runtime = 105 minutes | language = English | budget = | gross = $1,878,561 | awards = }} '''''The Slugger's Wife''''' is a 1985 [[romantic comedy]] film about a baseball star who falls for a singer. Written by [[Neil Simon]], directed by [[Hal Ashby]] and produced by [[Ray Stark]], the film stars [[Michael O'Keefe]], [[Rebecca De Mornay]] and [[Randy Quaid]]. It was distributed by [[Columbia Pictures]] and released on March 29, 1985. ==Plot summary== Darryl Palmer is a baseball player for the [[Atlanta Braves]]. He enjoys the fame and fringe benefits of bachelor life until he meets rock singer Debby Huston, falls in love and decides to settle down. Debby isn't ready to put her professional hopes on hold. But from the moment Darryl meets her, his own career takes off. He begins a full assault on baseball's single-season home run record of 61 (at that time) and considers Debby a good-luck charm, wanting her to be there at his games. Manager Burly DeVito appreciates that Darryl has found a settling influence in his life, but teammates Moose Granger and Manny Alvarado become increasingly aware of how obsessed Darryl is with Debby and how unhappy she has become. She feels smothered by her husband, who interferes with her career ambitions and goes into a jealous funk whenever she goes on the road. The couple breaks up, to the detriment of Darryl's game and his pursuit of one of baseball's greatest feats. He begins to fail on a regular basis and the team's playoff chances could be in jeopardy. Burly and his players concoct a plan to have another woman, hidden by shadows, pretend to be Darryl's wife, telling him everything he wants to hear. It works temporarily, then backfires. Debby comes back to try to work things out. Darryl does indeed hit his record-breaking home run, but it remains uncertain whether the couple's relationship can ever be what it once was. ==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Michael O'Keefe]] as Darryl Palmer * [[Rebecca De Mornay]] as Debby Huston * [[Randy Quaid]] as Moose Granger * [[Cleavant Derricks (actor)|Cleavant Derricks]] as Manny Alvarado * [[Martin Ritt]] as Burly DeVito * [[Lisa Langlois]] as Aline Cooper * [[Loudon Wainwright III]] as Gary * [[Georgann Johnson]] as Marie DeVito * Danny Tucker as Coach O'Brien * [[Lynn Whitfield]] as Tina Alvarado {{div col end}} ==Reaction== ''The Slugger's Wife'' was a total critical and commercial failure. The film has a 0% favorable rating on the Rotten Tomatoes web site. A March 28, 1985 review in ''[[The New York Times]]'' by [[Janet Maslin]] began: "It's a shock to find Neil Simon's name attached to something as resoundingly unfunny as this."{{cite newspaper|last=Maslin|first=Janet | author-link=Janet Maslin | title=Film: Neil Simon's 'Slugger's Wife' |date=29 March 1985|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9A04EED91438F93AA15750C0A963948260|accessdate=29 June 2015}} The film was nominated for a [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Original Song]] for the song "Oh, Jimmy!" According to the web site AllMovie.com, the film earned $1,300,000 in box-office receipts. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{imdb title|id=0090036}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|id=sluggers_wife}} * {{Mojo title|sluggerswife|The Slugger's Wife}} {{Hal Ashby}} {{Atlanta Braves}} {{Neil Simon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Slugger's Wife}} [[Category:1985 films]] [[Category:1980s romantic comedy films]] [[Category:1980s sports films]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:Columbia Pictures films]] [[Category:Films scored by Patrick Williams]] [[Category:Films directed by Hal Ashby]] [[Category:Atlanta Braves]] [[Category:Screenplays by Neil Simon]]

'''''Who U Wit?''''' is a [[compilation album]] released from American [[hip hop]] record label [[No Limit Records]]. It was released on May 25, 1999 and was produced by [[Beats By the Pound]], [[Master P]] and [[Meech Wells]]. This compilation charted much lower than No Limit's previous two compilations, 1998's ''[[Mean Green: Major Players Compilation|Mean Green]]'' and ''[[No Limit Soldiers Compilation: We Can't Be Stopped|We Can't Be Stopped]]'', only making it to #62 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and #22 on the [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]]. The album cover featured Master P as a member of the [[National Basketball Association|NBA's]] [[Charlotte Hornets]] during his ill-fated attempt to join the team for the 1998–99 season.

armlets, white cap | caption3 = Cape Fear }} {{Jockey colours footer}} The '''Woodcote Stakes''' is a [[Conditions races|conditions]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in [[Great Britain]] open to two-year-old [[Thoroughbred]]s. It is run over a distance of 6 [[furlong]]s and 3 yards (1,210 metres) at [[Epsom Downs Racecourse|Epsom Downs]] in June. ==History== The Woodcote Stakes, initially spelled Woodcot, was first run in 1794. It was run over the last half-mile of [[Epsom Downs Racecourse]]. [[Colt (horse)|Colts]] carried 8 st, with [[Filly|fillies]] carrying 7 st 1 lb.{{cite web|url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433066590963;seq=96;view=1up;num=32 |title=Racing calendar. 1794 |publisher=Babel.hathitrust.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-21}} The race was not run between 1800 and 1806, but was re-established in 1807 and run over the last six furlongs of Epsom track. Colts carried 8 st 3 lb, with fillies carrying 8 st 0 lb.{{cite web|url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433066590864;seq=88;view=1up;num=36 |title=Racing calendar. 1807 |publisher=Babel.hathitrust.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-21}} The following year the race was reduced in distance to half a mile and the weights the horses carried increased by two pounds.{{cite web|url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433066590856;seq=102;view=1up;num=48 |title=Racing calendar. 1808 |publisher=Babel.hathitrust.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-21}} The weights rose by a further pound in 1812.{{cite web|url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433066590815;seq=97;view=1up;num=33 |title=Racing calendar. 1812 |publisher=Babel.hathitrust.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-21}} In 1839 the race was moved to the new two-year-old course and the distance was increased to six furlongs.{{cite web|url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.b3498614;view=1up;seq=437;q1=woodcote;start=1;size=10;page=search;num=19 |title=The New sporting magazine v.17 (1839) |publisher=Babel.hathitrust.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-21}} In 1842 the subscription fee was set at 15 sov. The weights were also changes, with horses carrying one pound less and the winner of the Two-year-old Stakes at Gorhambury carrying a five-pound penalty.{{cite web|url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433066591045;seq=125;view=1up;num=49 |title=Racing calendar. 1842 |publisher=Babel.hathitrust.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-21}} In 1844 the subscription was reduced to 10 sov. In 1847 the weights were returned to what they were before 1842 and the penalty was removed.{{cite web|url= |title=SPORTING |publisher=''Manchester Courier and Lancashire General Advertiser'' |date=22 May 1847}} Winners of the race have included [[Leamington (horse)|Leamington]], [[Cremorne (horse)|Cremorne]], [[Surefoot]], [[Ladas (horse)|Ladas]], [[Sceptre (horse)|Sceptre]], [[The Tetrarch]], [[My Babu]] and [[My Swallow]]. The Woodcote Stakes held [[Conditions races|Listed]] status prior to 2017{{cite web|title=European Pattern Committee announces changes to the 2017 European Programme / 01 Feb 17|url=http://www.britishhorseracing.com/press_releases/european-pattern-committee-announces-changes-2017-european-programme/|website=British Horseracing Authority|accessdate=1 February 2017}} when it was downgraded and is sponsored by [[Investec Bank|Investec]]. ==Winners 1794-1799== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- style="background:#7d7; text-align:center;" ! style="width:36px;"| '''Year'''
